TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 72 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that:

The students and staff of the University of Queensland express their dismay at the lack of adequate federal government funding to our University, which has resulted, inter alia, in the erosion of our Library facilities-we note that:

PETITION.TITLE: Great Barrier Reef Marine Park
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:
The Great Barrier Reef is unique and is included on the World Heritage List.

Although the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act was to create a marine park to provide for the proper protection and management of The Reef, only 14% of the total area defined in this Act as the Great Barrier Reef Region has been declared marine park.
The only insurance against an oil drilling blowout in Reef waters is to prohibit oil drilling in the Region and its vicinity.
This can only be effected by declaring the whole area of the Region a marine park under the above legislation.

Your petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Government to take action to hold a referendum together with the next Federal Elections on the question that: 'The entire area of the Great Barrier Reef and its surrounding waters, defined as the Great Barrier Reef Region in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975, as amended 1978, be immediately declared a marine park under the provisions of that Act.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of Australia concerned about the high and increasing rate of divorce and family breakdown, convinced that the Family Law Act has weakened marriage by making divorce a trivial matter, the present Act paying scant regard to its own definition of marriage as a life-long union; and believing that the legal bond of marriage should be strengthened.
Humbly petition for the Family Law Act and the Marriage Act to be amended in order to:
1. Reject any moves towards divorce by post
2. Restore the former prohibition of marriages between close relatives by blood or marriage
3. Protect the rights and welfare of aggrieved partners of a marriage who are threatened with being divorced against their will
4. Ensure that in divorce judgments paramount attention be given to whatever course will best serve the welfare of dependent children of the marriage
5. Encourage counselling towards reconciliation
6. Restore objective tests to irretrievable breakdown of marriage in terms of:
i. intolerable behaviour; ii. desertion for two years; iii. separation for three years.
And we pray that you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our nation .
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Peter Baume (from 38 citizens) and Scott (from 18 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth our complete opposition to any stage of the Nuclear Industry.

We wish to inform you of our support for Union bans aimed against the Uranium Industry. We look towards a society that respects life, opposes violence, and recognises our total dependence on our global ecosystem.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Parliament take action to halt the mining, milling and export of Australian uranium and put people before profit.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognise that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection , storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognise that any system giving ' property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognise that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects namely:
(i) a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
(ii) subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programmes,
(iii) farmer unrest at seed prices,
(iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
(v) increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Evans (from 59 citizens), Primmer (from 42 citizens) and Robert Ray (from 38 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:
1. Note that legislation establishing plant breeders' rights in other countries has had serious adverse effects, namely:

(a) Virtual monopoly control of seed production has passed into the hands of a few large international corporations seeking to profit from the exclusive rights over plant genetic materials created by such legislation.

(b) The varieties of seeds available have been restricted mainly to hybrids which will not reproduce truly and will not grow without the aid of artificial fertilisers and pesticides, thus maximising corporate profits without regard for the interests of growers and consumers.
(c) The genetic diversity of crops has been eroded, rendering them vulnerable to disease and other environmental threats.

2. Recognise that maintenance of the genetic diversity of plant varieties is crucial to the continued well-being of the Australian nation, and take all necessary steps to preserve and promote such genetic diversity as a public resource and to prevent exclusive control over plant genetic materials from falling into private hands.

3. Defend the vital interests of Australian farmers and gardeners, independent Australian seed companies and their employees, and consumers of Australian farm and garden produce, by rejecting any proposal to legislate for the establishment of plant breeders' rights in Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth concern over Plant Variety Rights (PVR) legislation. We agree that:
1. PVR will inhibit the free exchange of genetic material for plant breeding.
2. PVR will not enhance Australia's access to plant varieties developed overseas but will encourage the dumping of unsuitable varieties on the Australian market.
3. PVR will restrict the public plant breeding program to basic research for exploitation by private enterprise and discourage breeding for disease and pest resistant varieties.
4. PVR will lead to the domination of the seed industry by foreign interests not responsible to the Australian people.
5. The proprietary rights granted by PVR will encourage the introduction of seed distribution and marketing monopolies and lead to seed price increases.
Your petitioners therefore pray that parliament refrains from enacting any legislation on PVR.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate: Does the Fraser Government accept the standard of ministerial responsibility applied in Great Britain and illustrated by Mr Hugh Dalton and Lord Carrington in respectively tendering their resignations? If the Fraser Government does not accept that standard, what standard applies under the present Government-the standard laid down by the present Prime Minister in 1972, the standard laid down by the Coombs Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration in 1976, or the standard allegedly suggested to the Attorney-General by an academic friend at lunch last Saturday, that is, that the Westminster system means 'what people do at any particular time'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Fraser Government has the highest standards of ministerial behaviour and has observed them, as history will have shown. There is no comparison between the English examples and the current situation. For instance, the example of Lord Carrington was, as I understand it, that of a senior Minister who gave the Government advice which subsequently proved not only inaccurate but also very significant with regard to the peacekeeping of that Government. It is an entirely different situation. Ministers of this Government are fully responsible to the Parliament for their administration. They appear here every parliamentary sitting day to answer for their administration. Indeed, the standards that the Commonwealth Government has established are as high as or higher than those of any parliament in the free world.
—I ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister have any preference for any of the three suggestions as to ministerial conduct which I specified in my question?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have said that the standards that we have established are the principles that we have pursued, and that they are acknowledged as being as high as or higher than those of any parliament in the free world.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. Is it a fact that individuals, if convicted of certain offences, are precluded from serving on or being appointed to the boards of directors of public companies? Are there any comparable restrictions on individuals becoming officials of trade unions? Does the Commonwealth have power to legislate to impose restrictions if it so desires? Is it a fact that the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union found that in 1981, of the 11 officials of that union, each had a criminal record, with numbers of convictions ranging from three to 61; only two had not served prison sentences; and only two had not used false aliases? In view of the immense monopoly power given to trade unions under our current system, would it not be appropriate for rules to be introduced to prevent them from being run by practising criminals?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I fear that Senator Hamer will be regarded as eccentric by Opposition senators for raising some aspect of the Costigan report other than that in which they seem interested, namely, matters involving the Government. In fact, the position is as outlined by the honourable senator in his question-that is, the report does detail a lamentable involvement of people with criminal records in that union. That is a matter to which I might ask the Opposition to direct some of its attention. There are no restrictions on participation in union affairs equivalent to the restrictions which are placed on people with criminal records participating in commercial activities. The Companies Act which was enacted by this Parliament and to which many members of the Senate contributed contains restrictions which inhibit participation in company management by people with criminal records. If someone has been convicted of an offence that carries a penalty of, I think, three months' imprisonment or more, there is an extensive period of debarment from participation in the directorship of a company. The time of disqualification is for five years after the conviction or five years after the release from prison.

ANSWER.PARA: I can understand Senator Hamer suggesting, in light of the findings of the Costigan report with respect to the painters and dockers, that similar restrictions on participation in trade union activities might be appropriate. It is certainly true that power and influence are wielded in this community not only through commercial organisations such as companies but also through the trade union movement. I will certainly ensure that the suggestion contained in Senator Hamer's question is carefully examined by the Minister and by the Government because I think there would be very considerable disquiet in this community at the ready way in which people with serious criminal charges to their names are able to take part in union activities in a way which is clearly not in the national or community interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —When did the Attorney-General first learn of the delay and incompetence which had taken place in the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office in Perth between 1975 and 1978, which is documented in the report of the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union- the Costigan report-and of which the then Crown Solicitor, Mr Neaves, was aware by March 1978? In particular, did he learn anything between March 1978 and the time of Mr Neaves's appointment as Secretary to the Department in July 1979? Why did it take so long for a matter of such gravity to be brought to his attention? Why did he appoint as permanent head someone who failed to pass on information about such appalling conduct in the Perth office? Is the Attorney-General taking any action about the then performance of the permanent head of his Department?

—I first became fully aware of the matters concerning the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office in Perth when the Costigan report was made available to the Government. I became aware of it in a telephone conversation on, I think, about 5 August. I was, in fact, on leave at the time. It was after that that I was fully briefed on the report and read the report. The statement Mr Howard made did reveal that there had been delays in the DCS Office in Perth. I pointed that out to the permanent head of my Department and asked him to tell me why counsel had not been re-engaged in relation to the matter. But, of course, that did not reveal at that stage the actual nature of the problems that were revealed as a result of Mr Costigan's investigation. Indeed, Mr Costigan's investigation rather overtook that because, shortly after I had mentioned that matter to the Secretary to my Department, Mr Costigan commenced his investigation. I was not aware of the matters referred to between March 1978 and July 1979. I think the rest of the question is not applicable.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I draw the Attorney-General's attention to the rest of my question which referred to the fact that Mr Neaves, as Crown Solicitor, knew of the delays. I ask: Why did Mr Neaves not inform the Attorney-General at the time? Can the Attorney-General be satisfied with Mr Neaves's performance as Crown Solicitor at that time? Should he not take some action in light of the fact that Mr Neaves is now the head of his Department?

—As far as the action of Mr Neaves as Crown Solicitor at the time is concerned, he assigned various people in the Central Office of the Department to deal with the matter after it was brought to his attention in March 1978. The question of dealing with these officers in both the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office in Perth and the Central Office in Canberra-the question of whether any of them should be charged-has been the subject of examination by Mr Bennett, a Deputy Secretary of the Department, who was assigned for that purpose after the Costigan report was made available. As everyone knows, Mr Bennett has charged three people in the DCS Office in Perth.
—None of this has anything to do with the question.

—Yes, it has. I have asked Mr Bennett why the charges were confined to people in Perth and did not apply to anyone in the Central Office. He has informed me that he did not believe that any particular officer in the Central Office who had charge of the matter was guilty of any offence which would justify the laying of charges. His view was based on the fact that the Central Office of the Department at the time was very short staffed, that there was an inadequate system in the office for supervision and so on.
—Whose fault was that?

—I am just coming to that. The point was that the Crown Solicitor at the time, now the Secretary to the Department, Mr Neaves, was concerned about this matter. He was the one who initiated, firstly, an organisation and methods review of the Crown Solicitor's Office and, subsequently, after submission to the Public Service Board, a joint management review of the Crown Solicitor's Office.
—And he never told you?

—Of course I knew of the joint management review. The honourable senator asked me whether he ever told me about the particular case. The answer is no. The question raises the matter of the performance of the then Crown Solicitor in March 1978. The fact of the matter is that it was at the initiative of the Crown Solicitor at the time that this joint management review was set up. That joint management review has now looked at the whole area of the Crown Solicitor's Division and recommendations have been made which have strengthened the role of the Crown Solicitor's Central Office and, in particular, there has been the appointment of a divisional manager responsible for supervision of the deputies' offices around Australia.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. I am sorry to ask a question about something that the people of Australia think is important! The question concerns the drought relief measures to assist farmers. Regarding the total funding of overdraft interest payments in excess of 12 per cent of debts in drought declared areas, I ask the Minister whether this is an open-ended arrangement or is limited to funding for this financial year or for what period. As to the 50 per cent subsidy on the purchases of fodder for livestock, I ask whether this is open-ended or limited to this financial year. Can the Minister tell me what is the estimated cost to the Commonwealth Government of these measures? Can the Minister tell me whether there is any burden on any of the State governments as a result of these measures?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of the drought was raised in the Senate when last it sat. Concern was expressed about the difficulties facing a large part of rural Australia. Unfortunately it is true that those difficulties have not been eased over the last week and a half by the hoped-for rain. Last week the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Nixon, announced new measures which augment the existing relief measures which are shared by the Commonwealth and the States. These measures were discussed when the matter was last raised in the Senate. As Senator Lewis indicated in his question, interest payments on debt at rates of interest exceeding 12 per cent are to be subsidised by the Commonwealth. This will be done totally by the Commonwealth. In other words, this does not fall within the broader, standard arrangements which are cost shared by the Commonwealth and the States. In the same way the Commonwealth will be the sole provider for the 50 per cent subsidy on the purchases of fodder for livestock.

ANSWER.PARA: It is true that these arrangements are open-ended in one sense, in that there is no quantitative limit placed on the extent of aid which might be provided under these measures. Clearly, however, there is a practical limit in terms of the amount of fodder and the amount of borrowing which farmers are likely to wish to undertake, particularly as they are to carry the first 12 per cent of interest which, at a time when rural incomes are being so severely dented, is still a very heavy burden for them. As I understand it, the arrangement is not open-ended as to time. My understanding is that it is restricted to the period in which there is a declaration of drought. That will vary from area to area. One hopes that the period of relief offered will be very short indeed, but we are subject to the seasons with respect to that. I will get clarification on that last point. I was not at the Cabinet meeting at which the details of these measures were finalised. It is my understanding that they are open-ended as to quantum but that there is a restriction as to time, which is the restriction as to when the drought finally breaks. I will have to obtain details of the estimated cost of these measures. I have seen a figure of $100m but I am not sure whether it relates to those two measures or to wider measures. I will have to chase a little further the question of cost which was raised by the honourable senator in his question.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note from the interjections the usual anti-rural slant which comes from the Opposition and the way it seems to object to any assistance being provided to Australians who are at present suffering considerable difficulties because of seasonal conditions. I am pleased to draw the attention of the Australian people to the very negative approach being adopted by the Opposition in this important matter.

—I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate a question. I refer to the fact that 24 of the world's leading archaeologists have written to the Prime Minister seeking an end to the destruction of the wilderness in South West Tasmania so that, among other things, archaelogical sites of international importance can be saved. I wonder whether the Minister who is talking to his colleagues would pay me the courtesy-if he is going to talk to his colleagues - of talking in a low voice while I am asking a question of the Leader of the Government.
—What about the interjections during answers? There is no such courtesy for answers.

—I make a practice of not interjecting. I hope that the Minister will pay me the same courtesy. Is the Leader of the Government aware that these letters, which have come from eminent professors at Harvard, Oxford and Cambridge universities, would have been received by the Prime Minister in June, yet up to now, some three months later, he has still not replied? Is it not a fact that the Federal Government's complete inaction on taking a statesmanlike lead in preserving South West Tasmania contradicts the fact that the Federal Government has explicitly recognised the national and international value of South West Tasmania by listing it on the National Estate and nominating it for World Heritage listing? In the light of highly qualified legal opinions from prominent Queen's Counsel and even the Attorney-General's Department which have unequivocally stated that the Federal Government has the power to save the Franklin River right now, can the Minister inform the Senate as to when the Federal Government will override an insignificant State Premier-one who owes his position to something less than 100,000 voters out of an Australian population of 15 million and one who is presently overseeing the destruction of the Franklin River-and ensure that a vital piece of international heritage is rescued?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that in today's media I first saw information concerning an approach by overseas archaeologists on the South West of Tasmania. I do not think I had seen mention of that before so I am in no position to answer the substance of Senator Chipp's question. I have no information on when the letters were received, and I have no information as to whether the Prime Minister has replied. Because I lack that information I will refer the question to the Prime Minister and seek his response.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology to media reports in the Australian of 1 September and on AM on 31 August in which Mr Barrie Hunt, the senior principal research scientist at the Australian Numerical Meteorology Research Centre-ANMRC-has reported that the Centre, which was set up to co-ordinate the drought research program, is to be disbanded in the middle of what is possibly Australia's worst drought. Can the Minister confirm this report and, if it is correct, will she advise what steps will be taken to continue the drought research program when it is most needed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I understand that no decision has been taken to terminate the climate research program, which includes investigation of drought mechanisms. The Australian Numerical Meteorology Research Centre, which is jointly operated by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and the Bureau of Meteorology, is to be closed as an entity. The research programs will continue to be carried out by CSIRO and the Bureau of Meteorology. The decision to close the ANMRC follows the report of the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions which charged CSIRO and the Bureau with promptly finalising the rationalisation process which had been proceeding relating to the weather and climatic activity of CSIRO and the Bureau.

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised that following a recent review in CSIRO of atmospheric science the executive of CSIRO decided to combine relevant parts of ANMRC and the existing divisions of cloud physics and atmospheric physics to form a new division of atmospheric research. Details of research activities in the new division will not be finalised until a chief has been appointed, but it is expected that research on drought mechanisms will be continued.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General. I ask: What discussions, if any, did he have between September 1977 and the tabling of the McCabe-Lafranchi report in May 1982 with the permanent head of his Department, with the Crown Solicitor or with the Treasurer regarding advice or action in relation to possible criminal or civil proceedings for tax evasion? What notes did the Attorney, the permanent head or the Crown Solicitor make of such discussions? Will the Attorney table all such notes for the determination of the Senate?
—The question seeks a good deal of detailed information and reference to documents. I will take that question on notice and provide a written answer.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Health assure the Senate that an intended alteration in the method of coding and payment on national health prescriptions-from dispensing pharmacists to departmental clerical staff-will not result in delays and increased costs? How will this new scheme affect the work load of pharmacists?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I assume that Senator Watson is referring to the proposed change for next year-1983-in processing arrangements for claims submitted by chemists for their dispensing under both the National Health Scheme and arrangements for repatriation benefits. The current keyboard equipment used to process pharamaceutical benefits claims is reaching the end of its effective life and is becoming difficult to maintain. In fact, I am advised that the current data entry equipment maintenance contractor has indicated that maintenance beyond the end of 1983 cannot be guaranteed. A new system of processing claims is being developed. This system is being designed to be more efficient, to require fewer staff and to reduce the amount of clerical coding work currently required at chemists. Of course, if the amount of coding work is reduced one would hope that the claims could be processed more expeditiously.

ANSWER.PARA: A basic objective of the system is to reduce the time taken to pay chemists' claims. The Pharmpay system is presently at an advanced stage of development. It is scheduled for pilot testing in Victoria during the first half of 1983 and a phased national implementation program is scheduled for the second half of that year. I believe that those points cover the concerns expressed by Senator Watson . If any of the matters which are worrying him are not covered by my answer perhaps he could raise them by way of a supplementary question.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Will not the proposed scheme increase the number of queries which have to be referred back to pharmacists?

—I imagine that that is a matter which we mainly will become aware of as a result of experience. But it is hoped it will not increase the number of queries; it is hoped that, because of the simplification to which I referred earlier, it will in fact reduce the number of queries.

—My question, which I direct to the Attorney-General, refers to a report on the Nationwide program last week that the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office in Sydney sought an opinion from Mr Lockhart, Q.C., some time during the period 1976 to 1978 regarding the possibility of prosecuting those involved in a bottom-of-the-harbour scheme. I ask the Attorney: Was such an opinion received from Mr Lockhart? Will the Attorney table that opinion, deleting the names of individuals to the extent legally necessary? Was it Mr Lockhart's opinion that the scheme in question could be prosecuted under the existing law? If so, why did that prosecution not proceed? Was the failure to act deliberate?

—The matter that was referred to on Nationwide was a matter raised in the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office in Sydney. It was referred to the office by, I presume, the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation in Sydney. An opinion was forwarded to it by Mr Lockhart, Q.C., in regard to possible action under a tax avoidance scheme which was not a bottom-of-the-harbour scheme.
—What was it?

—A liquidator had been involved and Mr Lockhart had been acting for the liquidator. It concerned certain changes in the rights of shareholders in a company. It involved a very complicated series of transactions. One of the major questions was whether they were commercially justified or a sham-type result. Mr Lockhart's opinion is a long and complicated one, but he did recommend that in his view there would be grounds for criminal proceedings under various matters including section 86 of the Crimes Act. The matter was dealt with in the Sydney office over several years.
—Oh!

—Well, these matters are fairly difficult, as the honourable senator knows. I was told about the matter and then it was reported on the Nationwide program. I directed the new divisional manager of the Crown Solicitor 's Office, Mr Loof, to make an investigation of the way the matter was handled by the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office in Sydney. He has given me a report which indicates that the matter was attended to by the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office but in the end the decision was that there was not sufficient evidence to take any proceedings.
—We have heard that story before-back in 1975 in Perth.

—The honourable senator will hear it again because this is one of the major problems. The report to me indicated that certain matters needed further explanation as to the way the matter was being handled. Officers were referred to who had participated in the handling of the file but who were no longer employed at the office. I wanted inquiries made of them about certain aspects of it, so the report is not complete. I have not completed my investigation of it and I do not intend to make a decision about whether Mr Lockhart's opinion should be tabled until I have completed my report. Obviously, if there is any question of any further action taking place, I would not be prepared to table Mr Lockhart's opinion for the reasons that I have already indicated in answer to another question from Senator Evans. One does not table opinions when proceedings are likely to take place or may take place. That is the state of play with regard to that matter.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. How much, if any, revenue has been lost through the failure to prosecute in this matter? Why has the Attorney preferred to accept the advice of his Department to that of Mr Lockhart on the question of whether sufficient evidence was available to prosecute?

—Let me make it quite clear that it is not a matter of my having accepted the advice of my Department in preference to that of Mr Lockhart. It is a matter of a file being dealt with in the ordinary way by the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office in Sydney, in the way that countless cases are dealt with--
—It is now six years old. It was 1976. Is the date right?

—Just a minute. Countless cases are dealt with every day all round Australia by deputy crown solicitors. Let me make it perfectly clear- Senator Evans knows perfectly well-that I do not and cannot deal personally with all these cases and make decisions on them. That suggestion is the most utterly absurd proposition. Senator Evans would have to be carried away with flights of fancy to believe that that was humanly possible. I have not made any decision in relation to this matter. I have ascertained that it was dealt with by the office in Sydney and it made a decision that there was insufficient evidence. There is no reason to believe that that was not a perfectly normal decision to make, one made continually by officers of the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office in the various States. I have indicated that I want further inquiries made as to whether that decision was a sound decision. Those inquiries are still taking place.

—Has the Minister for Education noted an article in today's Daily Telegraph in which the New South Wales Minister for Education is quoted as saying that more than 250,000 adults in New South Wales are illiterate and only 3,500 are receiving help to overcome the problem? Can the Minister inform the Senate whether the figures stated by the New South Wales Minister are correct and, particularly, whether the figure given by the Minister that about 6 per cent of the total population of Australia is illiterate is a reliable figure? If this is so, can the Minister advise the Senate what action his Department has taken to improve this catastrophic situation?

—I have seen the article to which Senator Lajovic has referred but have not had a chance to read it; I will do so. Therefore I am unaware of the figures which are attributed to the New South Wales Minister for Education. However, I have no doubt that they are of a correct order of magnitude. There are in this country a considerable number of people who are either completely illiterate or functionally illiterate to a greater or lesser extent. Whether or not the figures given are correct, the problem is certainly significant and worries all educationists and educational authorities. It may not be appropriate during Question Time to try to set out for my colleague-in spite of the interest which I know he has in this matter-all the initiatives that have been taken to try to address and overcome illiteracy, particularly adult illiteracy, in Australia. All educational systems and education administrators are concerned about the problem. The Commonwealth also has had an interest and concern in overcoming the problem. I will undertake to provide for the honourable senator later a schedule showing some of the main initiatives which have been taken.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General. Is it the case, as alleged on Nationwide on Friday 3 September, that the Deputy Crown Solicitor' s Office in Sydney was intructed to refer a bottom-of-the-harbour scheme to the Perth office of the DCS rather than use its own considerable expertise? Why was this so? Is it the case that on receipt of advice from Perth advising against prosecution, two officers of the Sydney Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office, including a senior officer, wrote memoranda strongly disagreeing with that advice? What was the fate of those dissenting memoranda? Were they transmitted to the Central Office of the Crown Solicitor? Who reviewed them? What weight were they given? Are they currently available?
—I did not see the program Nationwide on Friday 3 September. I understand that there was some further information--
—Did you get the transcript?

—Yes. I understand that there are some further allegations concerning the Deputy Crown Solicitor's handling of certain matters in the Sydney office. I have sought a report on the matter. I have not yet had a report on the other matter. I have dealt with the report that was raised on Nationwide on, I think, the night before. I have not yet had the report on the matter that Senator Tate has raised. I am seeking these reports as quickly as possible. I hope to have an answer to that question available later in the week.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PROPOSED HYDRO-ELECTRIC DAM: SOUTH WEST TASMANIA

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bonner Sen N.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment aware of an article appearing in today's Sydney Morning Herald wherein it is alleged that 24 internationally eminent scientists have written to the Prime Minister expressing concern over the proposed hydro-electric dam in South West Tasmania? The scientists pointed to archaelogical evidence of Aboriginal cave dwellers fifteen to twenty thousand years ago, evidence of man's most southerly existence at the time of the last Ice Age. The Oxford Research Director, Mr Derek Roe, wrote to Mr Malcolm Fraser:

QUESTION.PARA: If the sites were destroyed there would inevitably be much bitterness around the world, and the noisy drawing of parallels, with the appalling suppression in less enlightened times of the Aboriginal population in Tasmania.
Mr Roe completed his letter with the following request to the Prime Minister:
Please do what you can.
As an Aborigine and on behalf of all other Aborigines in this nation I ask the Minister: What will the Government do to protect the preservation of the heritage of my race?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bonner would be aware that earlier in Question Time today a question of a similar kind was asked. However, it did not cover some of the points raised by my colleague in his question. Senator Bonner asked a question relating particularly to the Aboriginal pre-history which may be lost if the caves in South West Tasmania are flooded. Honourable senators would appreciate the interest Senator Bonner has in this matter and his concern at such a possibility. The Tasmanian Government has made a decision to flood the Franklin River and to construct a hydro-electric dam, as honourable senators will know. It is within the powers of the State Government to proceed and to carry out this work. However, I would deplore the destruction of any sites of significance to Aboriginal Australians. In fact, I deplore the destruction of any sites of significance and I take the opportunity to voice concern at such a possibility.

ANSWER.PARA: The problem is that responsibility for land use and management decisions concerning State-owned land is primarily that of the State. However, since 1975 it has been this Government's policy to assist the Tasmanian Government to establish a national park of world significance in South West Tasmania to include a substantial wilderness area. This policy has been publicly reaffirmed several times and the Commonwealth has supported nomination of a large part of South West Tasmania to the World Heritage List. Having taken that action, the Government would now support the preservation of the wilderness and of course the sites which are of concern to Senator Bonner. I understand that the nomination of South West Tasmania will be considered by the World Heritage Committee in November this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General. I refer to previous questions concerning an investigation into the conduct of employees in the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office in Sydney in relation to delays in prosecuting cases of tax evasion. I ask the Minister: Is one aspect of the current investigation an allegation that there was a leakage of information from the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office about a Commonwealth prosecution of a private company, and is that allegation that the Commonwealth brief in fact was made available privately to lawyers acting for the company which was intended to be the defendant in the proceedings?
—That is not an aspect of the matter that I referred to in answer to Senator Evans's question. I am not aware of that particular allegation and will have to take notice of the question.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources aware of plans by the State Labor Party Opposition in Western Australia for future Australian Labor Party State governments to acquire a 15 per cent interest in the Ashton joint venture diamond project? Can the Minister verify the estimated costs of this scheme of $150m to buy a stake and a further $75m for such a State government to pay its share of development costs? Does the Government consider that the compulsory acquisition from and exploitation of resource discoveries of the private sector by the public sector is likely to inhibit further expansion and development of Australia's natural resources given the high cost and high risk of resource exploration, particularly at a time of fragile world metal and mineral markets and a particularly low demand for diamonds?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that there is a fragile market for diamonds throughout the world at this moment and it is true that any threat to upset stable marketing plans could have a very significant effect. As to the first part of the honourable senator's question, the Government has heard of the plans that he has mentioned. The suggestion is that the Western Australian Labor Party might intervene, but the precise details of the Opposition's intentions are not known at this moment and therefore it is very difficult to comment on them. Because of that it is very difficult to answer the second question, which is how much it would cost. Senator Crichton-Browne mentioned $150m. It could well cost that but I am not able to verify it. As to the third component of the question, the Government firmly believes that the implementation of such a plan would have damaging effects, as pointed out by Senator Crichton- Browne.

—I ask the Minister representing the Prime Minister a question without notice. I refer to the Government's recent decision not to grant any meaningful assistance to Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd in that company's hour of trouble. How does the Government reconcile its attitude to the level of protection for the steel industry with the level of protection for the car manufacturing industry? Would the Minister agree that prima facie it seems unfair that the Government should apparently willingly protect the automotive industry, which is almost wholly dominated by transnational companies, and not help Australia's largest company? Does the level of protection afforded to the motor car industry-there is a tariff of 57.5 per cent and strict quotas-seem generous when compared with the 10 per cent tariff protection of all steel imports? Does the Government not consider it arrogant on the part of General Motors-Holden's Ltd to oppose increased protection for the steel industry under these circumstances? Finally, does the Government not have a spark of gratitude in its heart for the $3,000m crude oil levy that it receives from the Bass Strait fields that were developed almost entirely at the expense of BHP at a time when few experts in this country were prepared to concede that there was much likelihood of finding oil in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Siddons's question is based on a series of false assumptions. The assumption that the Government has not sought to assist the steel industry is quite wrong, and he should know that. He ought to know, for example, that the Temporary Assistance Authority, having made an analysis, recommended a much lesser situation. He ought also to be aware that the Government's decision in the Budget context to allow companies to group their costs and profits and their general expenditure will enable BHP to combine its oil and its steel operation figures and, therefore, enable it to do something that it regards as very significant; that is, to provide significant new capital inflow into the steel industry for the future. The ability to combine company figures is a very significant benefit. Therefore, I reject entirely the situation as Senator Siddons has described it. Pending a full inquiry by the Industries Assistance Commission, the Government has agreed that the level of imports should be maintained at the existing level. It has also taken the action which I outlined previously.

ANSWER.PARA: I am quite astonished by the vigour of Senator Siddons's attack on the car industry in Australia. I should have thought that an industry which provides such massive direct and indirect employment benefits to Australia would be one that he would want to see fully protected. I should have thought that an industry which forms the basis for our defence industry as well as the rest of our manufacturing industry would deserve better than the kind of criticism that flowed from him. Therefore, I find the basis of the question totally wrong and I reject it.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the Gallery of Lord Lucas of Chilworth, who is a member of the House of Lords, and I extend to him a very cordial welcome to this chamber.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable senators-Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question without notice is directed to the Attorney-General, Senator Durack. Did the Attorney-General, on Sunday last, say publicly that the Australian Taxation Office had full knowledge of the implications of a test case about bottom-of-the-harbour tax schemes and did he also point out to the media that the Income Tax Assessment Act was administered by the Treasurer, Mr Howard? Is this statement of the Attorney-General meant to convey that it is the Treasurer and not the Attorney-General who should resign because of the failure to push ahead with legal action over tax avoidance schemes? Has the Attorney- General given such advice to the Prime Minister?
—The answer to the question is no. I was not suggesting the implication that Senator Ryan is drawing, perhaps as a result--
—You are trying to get yourself off the hook.

—No, I am not trying to get myself off the hook. I was simply dealing with a question put to me suggesting, as far as I can recollect, that the officers of my Department knew about the full ramifications of the bottom-of -the-harbour schemes when they were dealing with this file in Perth or, indeed, when it was referred to Canberra. I was simply pointing out that, although they knew that it was a very important case, there were other cases of a similar kind . The figures the Opposition has bandied about refer to thousands of billions of dollars worth of losses, or something like that. It was that sort of question, based upon these wildly exaggerated figures that Senator Ryan and her leader have been purveying. I was simply trying to put the matter into some perspective in saying that these people did not have full knowledge, that full knowledge of what was happening would have been held by the Taxation Office and not by them. That was all I was saying. While we are dealing with these figures that Senator Ryan and her colleagues have been bandying about, I point out that the fact of the matter is that the figure assessed by the Taxation Office as the amount of taxation losses resulting from bottom-of-the-harbour schemes is around $450m. That is a very large figure. It is the only official figure. Somehow or other that figure has been inflated by the Leader of the Opposition and others and has reached some fantastic figure involving billions of dollars.
—I ask a question of the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. I refer to the report that foot and mouth virus is to be brought into Australia for storage at the new--
—It is already here.

—If it is already here the situation is worse. I ask the Minister: Will the Government agree that the chance of its being released into rural industry is increased by having it in this country? If it is already in the country, will the Minister do whatever he can to remove it from the country? Will the Government advise the Senate just what advantages there are in having the virus within the country rather than leaving it outside the bounds of Australia?

—Maintaining live foot and mouth virus within the Australian National Animal Health Laboratory at Geelong is a matter which has raised concern among some sectors of rural industry. That concern has been reflected in questions asked in this place by Senator Lewis and by the honourable senator who has just resumed his seat. In response to those questions I have examined the matter from time to time. My understanding is that there is no cause for concern . This matter has been considered very carefully. A great deal of money has been expended on the laboratory at Geelong to ensure that Australia is in a position to protect its essential livestock industry. The availability of the virus is a part of being able to cope with any possible outbreak of foot and mouth disease- something which we fortunately have been able to avoid in this country by having very careful quarantine procedures. However, I will again go over the material which is available and get an authoritative reply for the honourable senator on this important question. I stress that it is a matter which has been raised over a period. I think something like $150m has been spent with respect to this project. It has been done with the most careful examination by the most expert people in Australia. I think there is no real cause for concern.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General. The McCabe- Lafranchi report concludes that the sale and assignment of shares in Kierad Pty Ltd-the company sold by the former Liberal Party bagman Syd Corser- was not an arm's-length transaction. Has the Attorney instructed his Department to investigate this matter with a view to prosecuting Mr Corser and the others involved?
—The answer is no. I have not instructed the Department to investigate that matter.
—Why not?

—As I have said, questions dealing with tax avoidance matters and tax files are referred by the Commissioner of Taxation to the Crown Solicitor if he wishes to take proceedings. The files are not referred to the Attorney- General, for reasons of the secrecy provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act. Senator Walsh raised a matter arising out of the McCabe-Lafranchi report. I will have that matter looked at. As I said, matters dealing with tax files and questions of tax prosecutions or tax recovery are referred by the Commissioner of Taxation to the Crown Solicitor but the matters are not referred to the Attorney-General.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the Attorney- General saying that he does not have the power to direct his Department to investigate this matter which, I might add, is a matter of public knowledge not only because of the McCabe-Lafranchi report but also because a liquidator has been appointed for this company; or is he waiting, as with a previous company in Perth, for the statute of limitations to make prosecutions impossible, which I think will be only about one more year?

—I am not saying that there is not a power in the Attorney- General to order certain officers of the Department to do certain things. I am saying that the way in which tax files are dealt with, as I have been describing , is that they are not referred to me. We have said and I have said that a special prosecutor and a special task force are to be appointed to deal with all bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. Legislation to establish the special prosecutor will be introduced into the Parliament this week. The task force is being assembled. It will be having its first meeting tomorrow. I have told the Victorian Premier that we will be engaged jointly with him in prosecution action where there are State and Federal matters. All these questions arising out of the McCabe-Lafranchi report or the Costigan report will be dealt with by the special prosecutor.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry studied the Gunn plan recently put forward for the reorganisation of much of Australia's meat industry's operations both at home and abroad? Did the Minister notice the resolution passed by the Tasmanian Farmers and Graziers Association last week seeking the establishment of a study committee to refine the Gunn scheme? Will he give consideration to organising a study committee to examine speedily the Gunn plan in detail, recommend any necessary refinements and provide urgently a workable set of marketing improvements for discussion, acceptance by the industry and implementation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention has certainly been drawn to the Gunn plan, as it has been called by Senator Archer in his question, which is a proposal which was put forward by Sir William Gunn some time ago to enhance the meat industry of Australia. It is a proposal which contains some suggestions which have given rise to some controversy within the meat industry. For example, Sir William has suggested that the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation be replaced with a non-statutory authority. He has suggested that $100m would have to be found in the first year of operation of the scheme, with industry having to find $25m of that. Large parts of the meat industry at the moment would not welcome our seeking to raise another $25m from them. Sir William has urged that there should be a single seller to markets which have a single purchaser, such as Korea and Japan. He has made a whole series of other suggestions which, as I say, have given rise to both interest and some controversy.

ANSWER.PARA: The question of the future marketing strategy for the meat industry has received a lot of discussion recently by producers. I think that Sir William Gunn's proposal has been something of a catalyst in leading to that discussion. The executive of the Cattle Council of Australia has published a national marketing strategy which attempts to pull together elements of that proposal and ideas from a number of other sources. My advice is that the new marketing strategy will be presented for endorsement to the Cattle Council's half-yearly conference in October. While Mr Nixon has been taking a very close interest and has had discussions with Sir William Gunn and a number of industry leaders about the proposal, the proper procedure at this stage is seen by him to be for the proposal to be discussed by the Cattle Council. I understand that that is what is intended by the association. At the moment the matter is still in the hands of industry. The Government feels that it is some way short of having to take a final position on the proposals which are currently being discussed but awaits with considerable interest the conclusion of the consideration which is being given to those proposals at the moment by industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier during Question Time Senator Hamer asked a question about the need for provisions in industrial law which might restrict people with criminal records from participating in the management of unions. I made reference to the fact that in the companies legislation which has been passed by this Parliament there were provisions which placed considerable restrictions on those with criminal records participating in the management of companies. Just to make a little more definite the answer which I gave earlier, I refer the Senate to section 227 of the Companies Act which refers to the fact that a person who is insolvent cannot act as a director or promoter of a company and that people who have committed a variety of offences cannot act as directors or promoters of companies, including people who have been convicted for an offence involving fraud or dishonesty which is punishable by imprisonment for a period of not less than three months. As I said in answer to the question, conviction for an offence of that sort can lead to disqualification for a period of five years after conviction or after release from prison. I simply say again that the presence of those provisions in the companies legislation seems particularly apt. This is the sort of provision which I am sure many people would feel is appropriate in relation to the trade union movement.

—On 24 August Senator Bonner asked me a question in respect of gloves to be used by members of the Australian Federal Police in the vicinity of Parliament House. I have received the following answer from the Minister for Administrative Services: The issue of items of uniform to members of the Australian Federal Police is a matter for the Commissioner. However, I am advised that as a result of a review by Sir Colin Woods earlier this year the issue of gloves was approved and immediate action to purchase suitable gloves was commenced. It is expected that these will be available for issue next winter. I should add that the Deputy Commissioner is not aware of any real complaints from members of the Force or their unions on this matter. Action was initiated by the Commissioner himself. I should also add that members of the AFP have recently been issued with new high quality cold weather jackets and where permanent guard posts have been established, such as around Parliament House and certain embassies, or in the embassy area, provision has been made for heating.

—Earlier in Question Time Senator Townley asked a question about the importation of live foot and mouth virus into Australia. To expand further on the answer which I gave, the position is that the design of the laboratories incorporates the very best microbiological security technology available and will enable any exotic disease agent, including foot and mouth disease virus, to be handled safely in the laboratories. The Government has decided that in principle that virus may be imported to the laboratories when their microbiological security is fully tested and found to be satisfactory. That policy is in line with recommendations made by the Australian Agricultural Council. However, the final decision on whether to import live viruses will take into account latest scientific developments in the field of foot and mouth disease, diagnosis and control, and this will include the state of development of the genetically engineered foot and mouth disease vaccines. In the intervening period it is proposed to consult fully livestock industry groups. A National Farmers Federation forum was held on the subject in late August and a group containing independent experts has been established to assess the laboratories' security.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Button proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The totally unsatisfactory and inadequate performance of the Attorney-General in relation to the issues raised by the Costigan Report.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional order having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In commenting on the subject matter of this matter of public importance the Sydney Morning Herald, on 26 August, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: What the man in the street will find hard to understand is the virtual immunity enjoyed by those people who have been instrumental in allowing the tax evasion industry to show such a staggering growth.

Of course the Sydney Morning Herald is not alone in raising that fundamental point about what the average Australian-whose taxes have increased very significantly under this Government-feels about the immunity which is extended to some people who have allowed the tax evasion industry to develop in the way in which it has. As the honourable member for Canning, Mr Bungey, put it on Friday, 3 September: 'There is no way that Senator Durack and his department head, Mr Neaves, can stay untouched. I think it is completely inconsistent for them both to stay'. The honourable member for Wilmot, Mr Burr, at the same time put it this way: 'Senator Durack should voluntarily stand down pending a full investigation, with the powers of a judicial inquiry, into the Attorney-General' s Department'. Of course those are just views of ordinary men in the Parliament but they reflect the concern of ordinary men in the street. Let me remind the Senate of the facts relating to the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes which were first detected by the Taxation Office in 1973 when a taxation investigator, Mr Todman, prepared material and gave it to the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office in Perth. That Office sought an opinion from the then Mr Brinsden Q.C. who advised that the promoter and two others involved should be charged with a breach of section 86 (e) of the Crimes Act.

By August 1975 the Deputy Crown Solicitor in Perth was instructed to proceed with the case as soon as possible. Nothing was done. As the Royal Commissioner, Mr Costigan, said, the file lay undisturbed in the bottom of the drawer for five years. The case involved tax avoidance schemes which accounted for hundreds of millions of dollars in unpaid tax. That case would have been a major test case for the revenue which, I would have thought, it was the duty of the Treasurer ( Mr Howard) and the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) of this country to be most astute to protect. After all, what could be a more prime responsibility for the Treasurer and the Attorney-General than to protect the revenue of the Commonwealth Government? This Government, as Professor Mathews has pointed out on a number of occasions, has shown great zeal in saving little items of expenditure, but no evidence of zeal has been shown in protecting the revenue of the Commonwealth.

The case which the Opposition again puts on this matter is that from 1977 on the Attorney-General should have informed himself about what his Office was doing, as a service department-as he describes it-to the Taxation Office and the Treasury, about these issues. The answer to that is: 'Well, look, I didn't know anything about it. I, the principal law officer of the Commonwealth, knew nothing about it'. The defence of the Attorney-General of Australia, the first law officer, to this charge of ignoring the manifest shortcomings of his Department, of ignoring what was not being done to protect the revenue of the Commonwealth, is: 'Ignorance is bliss in my case. I remained ignorant; it is a blissful state to be in'. The clear point is, and this is reflected in the passage I read from the Age editorial, that by his actions or inactions as the principal law officer of the Commonwealth, the Attorney-General encouraged the proliferation of these schemes. If he says it was not a matter of major public importance, a matter of major concern, one would have thought he would have been aware of the various reports of the Taxation Commissioner during that time that showed a steady concern about the proliferation of tax avoidance schemes. Not only that, in 1973-74 the report of the Taxation Commissioner complained about the lack of staff to investigate tax avoidance schemes. Those things are, of course, in the Treasurer's bailiwick. At the same time we are told today that there was a shortage of staff in the Crown Solicitor's Office to look at these schemes, and again the shortage of staff related to Government policies.

Of course, the Costigan report reveals grave failure to act by the Commonwealth Crown Solicitor's Office and, indeed, by implication, the Attorney-General. It makes it quite clear that the responsibility extends to the highest levels of the Department and ultimately to the Minister responsible. Since the publication of the report there has been further evidence that the Attorney-General's ignorance was not confined to the Perth office of the Crown Solicitor. The Sydney Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office was involved and asked for an opinion on a tax avoidance scheme in 1976. The opinion by Mr Lockhart, Q.C., was that prosecutions should be launched under the existing law. Nothing, again, was done by the Crown Solicitor's Office. The Attorney again says today that it was not a matter which he had brought to his attention or about which he inquired.

One might ask what other schemes are involved and in what other offices has inaction of the same kind occurred. If Perth was involved Sydney would have been involved-that was obvious. But one would ask, by way of rhetorical question, was Senator Durack aware of the Lockhart opinion and, if not, why not? We understand from Question Time today that he was not aware until relatively recently. We accept that Senator Durack may not have had the slightest idea what his Department was doing. But the question then remains: Why is he a Minister in the Government if he has no idea what his Department is doing about this matter of greatest public importance? As I said, sins are those of omission and relying, as it were, on ignorance. By his own admission he neither knew nor cared what was going on in his own Department. As the Age put it on--

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course he cared.
—Oh, how could he have cared if he did not know, Senator? He never asked any questions. As the Age put it on 6 September:

SPEECH.PARA: The record indicates he is a bad administrator . . . A good administrator runs a tight department and puts the fear of God into those senior bureaucrats who do the day to day supervising.

Well, perhaps that is a very high standard which one might expect in some country like the United Kingdom. But we have got used to not expecting it from this Government. The Costigan report has led to evidence of affairs in the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office in Sydney. Evidence keeps trickling out day by day. We ask: When will the Attorney-General begin to take responsibility for some of these matters?

What the Attorney-General does, of course, is to say, first of all: 'Ignorance is bliss; I knew nothing about it'. Secondly, he hides behind section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act-the most shabby performance I have ever heard from a Minister in this Parliament. It is quite clear that section 16 of the tax Act, the so-called secrecy provision, provides no real smoke-screen even for the present Attorney-General. Of course, what section 16 does is to prevent from being revealed the particular details of tax returns and names of persons paying tax. That is a legitimate provision in that sense. But what Senator Durack says in answer to that is that he was not allowed to know. That is absolute rubbish and the Attorney-General ought to recognise it. He could have informed himself of the general progress of cases in his Crown Solicitor's Division but he did not bother. The facts are that between 1975 and 1980 the opinions of at least four or five Queen's Counsel were available which advised that the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes could be prosecuted under the existing law. Following the report of the Costigan Royal Commission two relatively minor officials of the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office in Perth, and the Deputy Crown Solicitor in Perth, Mr Massie, were suspended. The report of the Costigan Royal Commission states:
On 3 April 1979, the Crown Solicitor wrote formally to the Taxation Office advising that the evidence-
He was referring to the evidence for prosecution-

was insufficient. The letter did not condescend to particulars. It could not have done. At that time there was no-one in the Crown Solicitor's Office who had a grasp of the facts sufficient to allow the particularising of the supposed deficincies

There was nobody in the Crown Solicitor's Office in all that time who could be described as having had a grasp of the facts. One might add the present Attorney -General to that. TALK.START.PARA: —I just repudiated that inference.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition assumes that the way in which the Government should have tackled tax avoidance, or evasion, was to prosecute in those cases referred to as being in the Perth or Sydney files. The fact of the matter is that this particular form of tax avoidance or evasion, known as the bottom-of-the-harbour scheme, was only one of a countless number of such schemes. I am told that something in the order of 100 different forms of artificial tax avoidance schemes proliferated during the years we are discussing. As I pointed out the other day, they commenced in the early 1970s and one of the first and worst examples was the Curran scheme, which became evident during the time of the Labor Government. I am not saying that because the Labor Government did not do anything about it that justifies this Government's doing nothing. Senator Haines seems to get upset when I mention this. That is the very reverse of what I am saying. I am saying that when these matters really became evident and the full picture was given to this Government and the Treasurer, Mr Howard, he instigated and the Government adopted a new vigorous and active policy of tackling these tax avoidance schemes with specific legislation.

That was the policy that Treasurer Howard introduced and the schedules tabled in the Senate a fortnight ago reveal the wide number of measures that this Government took over the years to tackle and to stamp out these schemes. Admittedly, the Commissioner of Taxation did refer a bottom-of-the-harbour case, which he thought was a good test case, to the DCS Office in Perth in 1975 and I do not justify the mismanagement that occurred in that case. The Commissioner of Taxation had found that prosecution was not progressing in that case for the simple reason that the evidence was not sufficient, and that maybe if the Perth office had got on with it it may have been able to obtain further evidence. When the Commissioner of Taxation found that the proliferation of this scheme was becoming a serious matter, he then took the scheme to the Treasurer and the Government decided it would tackle the scheme by legislation. The legislation is the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act. I think everybody agrees that it has been highly successful in stamping out this form of tax evasion.

As I have said, prosecutions may have been of some benefit in arresting the development of the scheme. I do not know; it is hypothetical. Certainly prosecution, as such, was no long term answer to this particular scheme. In any event, prosecutions involve investigations, committal proceedings, trials by jury and so on. They take a great deal of time and a great many resources. Probably each case would have to be dealt with separately. There were probably thousands of these cases. The idea that they could be resolved by prosecution is quite unsustainable. The proper way to deal with these cases was the way in which the Government decided to deal with them and the way in which we dealt with them, and the proof is the success that the Government had in dealing with them by means of the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act. I should like to refer to the actions that the Government has decided to take on my recommendations. This is an attack on me, and I believe that I should refer again to the actions that the Government has taken in response to Mr Costigan's findings. Before deciding to set up the special prosecutor, the Government had already retained Mr Gleeson as a special adviser in these bottom-of the-harbour cases. The Perth case, which was identified by the Commissioner of Taxation as a major test case-this was reaffirmed by him-was put together by an officer from the central office who went to Perth. He spent 80 hours putting the case together. The brief was delivered to Mr Gleeson for his advice. In the light of Mr Costigan's views expressed on that case, the Senate might be interested to know that Mr Gleeson has advised us that further inquiries are necessary before that prosecution can proceed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, it is six years out of date, that is why.
—I am simply pointing out, Senator Button, that these cases are cases that require a great deal of evidence and investigation.
—I bet they do if they have been in the bottom drawer for five years.
