SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General, Senator Durack, seems a little wounded about the Opposition raising this matter again today. Let me tell him that an awful lot of people are wounded about the fact that he continues to sit here occupying a ministerial seat after the scandals that have been revealed by the events of the last few weeks. Particularly wounded are the seven million Australian taxpayers who, each of them, are and have been forced to pay somewhere between extra hundreds of dollars and even, perhaps, extra thousands of dollars-depending on how it is calculated-by virtue of this Government's failure to effectively prosecute one particular notorious class of tax avoidance -tax evasion schemes, the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes that came prominently to departmental and public attention at least from 1977 or 1978.

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose that it is fair to say that what began as only a mutter of demands for the Attorney-General's resignation has become over the last two weeks something rather more approaching a roar. It is easy to see why that has happened when one witnesses the blinkered self-righteousness, the blinkered, blinking indifference demonstrated by the Attorney-General today to the nature of his responsibilities and to the nature of the fault that he has perpetrated, been responsible for, over the last few years of his stewardship in his role. The roar of demands for his resignation has come from the editorials of about 10 major Australian newspapers. It has come as well-I do not know whether one can describe it as a roar or a squeak in this case-from Senator Withers, Mr Peacock, Mr Burr and Mr Bungey, on the Government's own side.

It is clear that these cries can no longer simply be ignored in the way in which they are being ignored by the Attorney-General here today. Following the cries which came first from the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats, the cries have now extended right across the political spectrum and appear across the full range of responsible organs of public opinion. The point that every one of these responses has been making is that the buck simply has to stop somewhere if our system of democracy is any longer to deserve that name, and that in the Westminster style of democracy that we continue for better or for worse to observe, in most respects, the proper place for that particular buck to stop in the kind of circumstances evident in this case is with the Minister himself.

To say that the blame in this case rests not with the Minister but with his Department, but then to say that within the Department it is not the departmental head who shares the responsibility-even though it is evident that in this case he personally bears a large measure of the blame-but that the blame should be allocated down the tree somewhere to the desk officers who are immediately concerned, is simply to make a farce of the whole system. The buck passes, the fault passes, and we end up with what an editorial in the new Queensland newspaper, the Daily Sun, very aptly described on 30 August 1982 as a system of no-fault democracy. That is what we have as a result of this; a system of no-fault democracy in which the buck is constantly on the move and certainly does not rest where it should-on the Minister's desk.

Two particular claims have been made by Senator Durack and those few on the Government side who have been heard to publicly defend him about the position as it stands in the aftermath of the Costigan report. The first kind of claim that has been made is that the Westminster system in its purer British form might be applicable to this sort of situation but that the pure Westminster system does not apply in Australia. The second kind of defence that has been made is that to the extent that any kind of doctrine of individual ministerial responsibility is applicable in Australia today, it is one that depends on individual ministerial culpability-the personal failings of the Minister concerned-and that there is no question of personal failings in this case. Let me make as my contribution to this debate what I hope will be the effective demolition of both those propositions-firstly, that the Westminster system is not applicable in its British form in Australia in relation to responsibility and, secondly, that there is no element of personal failing or culpability so far as Senator Durack is concerned.

As to the first issue, there may be some differences in the Westminster system as it applied in Australia, not least those which are demanded by the existence of the Senate playing a role which has no exact equivalent in the United Kingdom . But the Government is very quick to rely on the operation of Westminster conventions in Australia when it suits its purpose to do so. No one has been quicker to rely on Westminster conventions and the Westminster traditions of responsible government than Senator Durack. I remind him, if he is prepared to be reminded on this issue, of what he was constantly heard to say during the debate on the freedom of information legislation about the justification for non -effective access by the public and interest groups to the files that existed within department's because there was a system of ministerial responsibility in which the buck stopped with the Minister and could not be cast off to individual public servants. I also remind Senator Durack of what he and others on the Government side have been saying about the inapplicability of the concept of fixed term parliaments because of the system of Westminster-style responsible government that operates-and operates properly-in this country.

Certainly, Malcolm Fraser-Senator Durack's leader pro tem-was in no doubt about what the Westminster system meant in its application to Australia in his much quoted statement. Let me read some of it. It appears in the book entitled 'Who runs Australia?', being the proceedings of the thirty-eighth summer school of the Australian Institute of Political Science in 1972. On page 182 of that document Malcolm Fraser states:
It is certainly true that ministers cannot be aware of everything that occurs in their departments.

I interpolate that he readily acknowledges, as we on this side readily acknowledge, the force of what Senator Durack stated to be the childish proposition that, of course, Ministers cannot be aware of every small thing that goes on in their departments. Nobody disputes that. But Malcolm Fraser accepted that point and went on to state:

They ought to be aware of all the major matters and therefore can be clearly and directly responsible for them. But if a major blunder occurred in a department, of real importance to Australia, and if the Minister were unaware of it, that minister should accept responsibilty for the mistakes of his department and offer to resign.
Further down the page, relevant to the claim of the irrelevance of Westminster to Australia, he said:

It might be said that this used to be the position but that experience in other countries and in America has made it outdated. Well, if this is the claim, it shows a complete misunderstanding of the difference between the British system of government and the American system, in which the separation of powers dominates.
On page 200 of the same volume Mr Fraser states:

There are people who think that the doctrine of ministerial responsibility is an outdated and an outworn one, whether from misuse or disuse or for any other reason. I still believe it to be a valid and honourable and proper doctrine. If it does not work as it should, I suggest that instead of turning the system upside down we should give some thought to seeing how the doctrine of ministerial responsibility could be made to work in practice in the way it should in theory.

Does the Attorney-General, anyone else on his side or Malcolm Fraser himself now repudiate that statement? The Coombs report in 1976 stated that a Minister ought to resign if 'the action which stands condemned was theirs, or taken on their direction, or was action with which they ought obviously to have been concerned' . Again, there is that element of responsibility if the nature of the subject matter is such that it ought to demand this kind of ministerial attention.

To dismiss, as Senator Sir John Carrick did today, the Lord Carrington example is again to misunderstand and misapply the Westminster system as it is now operating. There was no suggestion of direct and immediate personal culpability in relation to Carrington. Rather the suggestion was that the Foreign Office would be discredited so long as he remained in office because of the obvious ineffectiveness of its advance warning system. That was why Carrington resigned. The reason was not that he personally had given any false or wrong advice to the Government but that he felt that his continued presence on the stage would discredit the Government. Senator Sir John Carrick, in accepting the utility of the Carrington example, of course points to the continued power of the Westminster conventions and their applicability in Australia. But in misstating the operation of that convention he effectively served to tap another nail into Senator Durack's coffin. What happened in the Carrington case is exactly, for the sorts of reasons that were relevant in that case, what we say should be happening here.

Senator Durack has been much less clear than his colleagues about what the Westminster system is all about. On 3 September he said that he had been reading up about it only in the last week. Now he has made up his mind what it is about. He says that it is about is how a Minister reacts when something is brought to his attention. We will see in a moment how he reacts. I simply make the point that that perception of the ministerial responsibility doctrine is a very innovative one in Australian constitutional jurisprudence, owing no credit to any forebears in literature or elsewhere, and being, if fact, a very recent invention of the last seven days, of the Attorney-General himself.

The reality is that any system of democracy which operates on the basis of a parliamentary system and responsible government must operate in a way that the buck stops somewhere. It is in the sort of case that is very much in issue now that the buck ought to stop with the Minister. The buck should stop with the Minister in three situations. The first is where the Minister is obviously personally culpable because of some affirmative action which he idenfensibly has taken. Nobody is suggesting that that is in issue here. Secondly, it is the case that someone is personally culpable and should resign when he negligently fails to act in a way that all the circumstances as they exist at the time demand that he should act. The third circumstances in which a Minister ought to resign, on a proper view of the operation of his convention in Australia today, is in circumstances where a major blunder is made on a matter of real importance to the country and not a minor peccadillo buried somewhere within the bowels of the department. We readily acknowledge that that cannot be right. But when a major blunder is made and when the matter is of real importance-as is the case with this loss of hundreds and perhaps thousands of millions of dollars through failure to prosecute tax avoidance schemes-the Minister's responsibility is clear.

Senator Durack does not rest-nor do his supporters-with the defence that the ministerial responsibility convention is inapplicable in Australia. They go on to say that to the extent that it is applicable, it is only applicable in circumstances in which the Minister is personally culpable and has demonstrated some obvious personal failing. Senator Durack, of course, denies-those speaking on his behalf deny-that there has been any such failing. They all seem to be- Senator Durack particularly-under the delusion that he has been neither incompetent nor negligent in the conduct of his portfolio. That is a claim which simply cannot stand up. He has repeatedly claimed that he first became generally aware of bottom-of-the-harbour prosecutions-again he has made the point in Question Time today-only with the McCabe report and only fully aware of the Perth major test case after the tabling of the Costigan report last week. Senator Durack seems to fail to appreciate that the failure to ask the right questions when any reasonable person would be asking questions is just as much a matter of personal culpability as being caught with your fingers in the till. Culpability can arise through the negligent discharge of one's duties.

I believe that while the Attorney could be forgiven for not asking those questions up until 1977 or 1978 when, as John Howard said in his Press statement in June, these schemes really started to take off and first came to public attention and their degree of iniquity was appreciated, it seems to me, to the Opposition and to the great mass of editorial writers and Australians who are witnessing this debate, that that sort of defence simply cannot hold up over that period. It certainly cannot hold up in the context of the run-up to the 1980 enactment of the crimes tax offences legislation. The whole point was that the claim was being made that no prosecution could stand up and that the other techniques available had all failed and would all fail if they went to court, so there had to be legislation. If the Attorney did not satisfy himself about things at that time he was, in our view, negligent.

The situation is that the Attorney is caught on a three-horned dilemma. If he did in fact ask what was going on in 1978 to 1980, on that hypothesis, of course he has been lying now in what he has told the Senate today and what he has said over the last three weeks. Secondly, on the second hypothesis, if he did ask what was going on and he settled for the answer that he then got from his Department, that part of the dilemma sets him up as obviously someone, to be blunt about it, who is a fool in accepting that advice. On the third hypothesis, if he did not ask what was going on, in all the circumstances as they existed at the time and as they exist now, he is negligent. The Attorney has to have it one of those three ways. If he resists, as he is no doubt entitled to, the suggestion that he is lying, that is one thing. The only other options are that he has either been foolish or negligent. Either way the substance of this matter of public importance is clearly demonstrated.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I accepted the word 'lying' because I think you were referring to a hypothetical situation.
— Exactly.
—It is on that basis that the Chair accepts that word. You are very aware, as we are, that that is a most unparliamentary form of language.
—I appreciate that, Mr President. I stated it as a hypothesis.
—I accept that.
—Thank you, Mr Attorney.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Senate is this afternoon debating a matter of alleged public importance moved by the Leader of the Opposition ( Senator Button) in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The totally unsatisfactory and inadequate performance of the Attorney-General in relation to the issues raised by the Costigan Report.

What we have heard this afternoon has been a somewhat pathetic rehash of a motion which was debated in this chamber the week before last. That motion was unsuccessful. This debate is as uninteresting and lacking in novelty as perhaps someone who suggests that tax evasion-tax avoidance schemes are still a major problem in Australia. What we are talking about, I suppose, arising from the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union are two major points. One is tax evasion. In relation to that, the necessary steps include closing the gaps in the legislation, recovering the tax, if possible, and prosecuting offenders when that is appropriate. I believe that not even the Opposition in its most ambitious, in its most hopeful, moments could suggest that this Government has not been active in amending the legislation to close the gaps, in taking steps to endeavour to recover the tax, and has not been taking steps to conduct prosecutions when they are appropriate.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has taken you seven years.

—I will come to the record of the Australian Labor Party in this matter in a minute. Up there, Khemlani! Let us turn to the second point, namely, the administration of the Attorney-General's Department and the issue of ministerial responsibility. They are the issues which I presume are the ones to which the Opposition is referring. They have nothing to do with the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union and their mates in that union who participate in the formation of Labor Party policy and vote in relation to various matters, the subject matter of that report.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the tax avoidance industry. I think that everyone would accept that since 1980 that industry has been killed. It is dead, I think its death can be shown by the fact that one of its principal promoters, one of the principal people involved in it, recently passed some cheques which bounced. That is a fair indication of how dead the industry has become. There are two issues involved in this matter. One is the recovery of tax which has been avoided. I think the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) has outlined clearly this afternoon and in other statements the steps which have been taken in relation to that and I do not need to dwell on it. In relation to the administration of the Attorney- General's Department, again the Attorney has outlined in considerable detail the very sequence of a variety of steps taken by him to ensure that any deficiencies in the administration of the Department are rectified and that those who have committed breaches of their obligations are, in the appropriate way, placed on trial in relation to those breaches. Notwithstanding the fact that the Attorney has taken all of those steps, notwithstanding the fact that this Government has made more amendments to the tax legislation to cover the loopholes as each of them have appeared than has any previous government, the Australian Labor Party wants to criticise.

Let us look at the Labor record in this field, the record of the people who are making these criticisms. I suppose we could say that they claim that they acted with the speed of light. Yet we hear that on 1 December 1974 the then Labor Treasurer, Mr Crean, announced that the Government was considering amending the law to cover the Curran scheme. That announcement was made on 1 December 1974. By the time they went out of office 12 months later they had not done a thing to amend the law in relation to the Curran scheme. Twelve months from the time they announced they would take steps to amend the law they were still considering it.

Let us look at another matter in this track record of humbug. We are told- Senator Button said this this afternoon-that they first discovered the bottom-of -the-harbour schemes in 1973. Yet in 1975, two years later, they got around to authorising a prosecution. For 12 months nothing was done about the Curran scheme. It took them two years, apparently-from 1973 until 1975-to get around to authorising launching one prosecution. Then in the next six months they did not follow it up because, under their administration, it was permitted to lie in the bottom drawer of the desk of an officer in Western Australia. Let us just have a look at the record of the people who are throwing criticisms around this chamber . Let us just remember that the sorts of actions to which I have just referred are from the same group who brought us the Khemlani and Iraqi breakfast affairs. Let us just wonder with what honesty and with what integrity they can attack the present Attorney-General. I would rather adopt the attitude which was adopted by the Australian in an editorial dated 7 July 1982. I think that sums up the attitude of many Australians to the work which has been done by this Attorney- General. The editorial states:

Australia's Attorney-General, Senator Durack, deserves the thanks of our business community for the agreement he has reached with the US Government on the extraterritorial application of American anti-trust laws.
Even more importantly, the editorial goes on to state:
. . . what has been achieved is of great value and reflects considerable credit on Senator Durack. He is one of the least flamboyant of politicians but, as he has again shown--
I emphasise the words 'again shown'-
Australia is well served through having him as our Attorney-General.

Part of the misconception in relation to this matter arises from the fact that people do not appear to have a clear idea of the real nature of ministerial responsibility. Those people include the noisy one who has been trying to interject all the time to drown out my voice while I am speaking and have the floor. I refer to Senator Evans. Let me just point to what the real nature of ministerial responsibility is. I believe it was extremely well set out in paragraph 4.22 of a report by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, which states:
No part of the Westminster system has been so thoroughly criticised, nor has any part so thoroughly changed, as the doctrine of individual--
I emphasise 'individual'-

ministerial responsibility. It must be remembered that this doctrine developed in the days when departments of state were small and it was a reasonable assumption that ministers of state were familiar with everything that went on in their departments.
Paragraph 4.30 of that report states:

In our view it is clear that the theory and practice of individual ministerial responsibility bear increasingly little relationship to each other. The short answer to those who have expressed views that freedom of information legislation will adversely affect the operation of the doctrine of individual ministerial responsibility is that they are in fact worrying about something which has long ceased to exist in practice.

I stress those words 'long ceased to exist'. One of the authors of that report is the honourable senator across the chamber who is attempting to interject. Let us get back to the facts of ministerial responsibility. Let me refer to what Professor Gunn has said. I have many quotations to use but I will use only a few of them. It is incredible, considering the amount of written work that has been done, the findings of Senate committees and so on, that people still continue to put up what is humbug and what, at the risk of being unparliamentary, I could call deceitful in the public debate which has taken place in relation to Senator Durack. Professor Gunn, Professor of Public Administration at Strathclyde University, said:

By the early 1960s there was general agreement among British academics that the responsibility of Ministers for the actions of their departmental civil servants was one of the weaker conventions of the British Constitution. Finer had demonstrated that it was increasingly rare for Ministers to resign . . .
Professor Gunn went on a little later to say:
Yet if responsibility no longer implied culpability it was still seen as requiring answerability--

That is where the mistake occurs. That is where the real difference lies. The difference lies between the collective responsibility of the government responsible to the lower House of the parliament and the individual ministerial accountability of each Minister to either House of the parliament. Professor Gunn continued:
so that the Minister and only the Minister was expected to explain and account to Parliament for his department's actions.

Example has been given many times of Lord Peter Carrington's resignation earlier this year in relation to the Falkland Islands crisis. I do not believe this matter has been accurately referred to by Opposition speakers. Lord Carrington said that in his view much of the criticism was unfounded. He said:
I have been responsible for the conduct of that policy and I think it right that I should resign.

TALK.START.PARA: —He was responsible as the ministerial head.

—He was responsible for the policy. I inform Senator Evans that the emphasis is on the policy. He said that he had to take responsibility for his actions and his judgment had been seriously questioned. He did not see how he could be very valuable to the Government during the coming weeks if his judgment was constantly being questioned. His judgment, his policy and his actions were in question. Even though he did not admit that it was wrong, he said that it was his policy which was being questioned. There are numerous references which I could give in conclusion. The public and administrative law plenary session on ministerial responsibility in modern parliamentary government formed part of the third Commonwealth and Empire Law Conference held in Sydney in 1965. A paper was presented there by the then Attorney-General, the Honourable B. M. Snedden. I refer to other matters which are set out in great detail by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs between paragraphs 4.22 and 4.30, which include observations by Professor Finer, Professor Emy and the Right Honourable J. M. Fraser, who said in a publication which was then stated to have recently appeared in--
—All of this was arguing the need for freedom of information legislation which this Government--
—The honourable senator tailors his argument according to his purpose. That is just about it. In the Australian Journal of Public Administration the present Prime Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: It has always been difficult for a minister to be aware of-let alone directly involved in-every exercise of the powers conferred upon him. I do not know why this ministerial inability to be Superman should surprise anyone.
That is the sort of thing that has been written recently by the current Prime Minister. I go on to quote from the third edition of The British Cabinet by John Paul Mackintosh, which states:
One meaning that does cause some confusion is the alleged obligation on a minister to resign when he or one of his subordinates has blundered.
He went on to say:
. . . where the fault lay with a subordinate and the Cabinet was prepared to stand by the minister.
In this situation--
I emphasise the following words-
there had never been any constitutional obligation to resign.

That is what the third edition of J. P. Mackintosh's book states. Yet we have heard all this humbug and misrepresentation by various Labor speakers calling upon the British Westminster system of high principle and resignation to apply. Let it apply. It is set out there. There are many other examples which I can quote. In summary, what we have is a situation where very considerable action has been taken on tax avoidance. Action has been taken on the allegations of wrong-doing by various departmental officers. An active and quietly effective Attorney-General has, I believe, carefully moved through the taking of those actions. We have had a massive misunderstanding of the nature of ministerial responsibility and a misleading of the public as to what that is. We have a situation where no act of commission or omission has been shown.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter before us today has been described as a matter of public importance. It seems that element of this debate has been ignored by Government senators.
—The painters and dockers.

—Yes, the painters and dockers are also a matter of public importance. I point out to Senator Teague that at least the painters and dockers attack their own. In fact, one could say that they are doing some people a public service by getting rid of one or two of them. On the other hand, the people who take part in tax evasion are hurting everybody. Senator Evans mentioned earlier that taxpayers generally object to the fact that they are paying higher taxes because of tax evasion. I venture to say that pensioners and beneficiaries are not too chuffed at the fact that their pensions and benefits are kept unnecessarily low because the Government's coffers are depleted by the failure to pay in a particular amount of money. Whether the amount is hundreds of millions of dollars or billions of dollars is irrelevant: Money is not going into the Government coffers for use where it is needed. That is a matter of public importance. The matter was raised by the Royal Commissioner, Mr Costigan, in his latest report on the activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. The issues raised there have to do with topics such as ministerial responsibility, or lack of it, tax evasion and the part played in encouraging tax evasion by incompetence, lethargy, and apathy on the part of some sections of the Attorney-General's Department.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Peter Rae made the point that honourable senators on this side of the House have misrepresented the concept of ministerial responsibility. Certainly, the Westminster system argues for full responsibility for actions and omissions occurring within a department, limiting those actions to major matters. Certain senators and members on the Government side have been rather flexible over the years in their attitude to ministerial responsibility. It has been pointed out in previous debates that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has made the point that it is certainly true-he said this in 1972-that Ministers cannot be aware of everything that occurs within their departments. I for one, and my colleagues I am sure, would not disagree with that any more than we would disagree with the argument that parents cannot be held responsible for everything that their children do. But parents who neglect to pay any attention at all to what their children are doing and who allow them to run riot and to do as they please-

TALK.START.PARA: —Over a period of years.

—As Senator Mason said, over a period of years, must be held responsible. That is the point that honourable senators on this side of the House have been arguing with regard to ministerial responsibility. As Mr Fraser pointed out in 1972, Ministers ought to be aware of all major matters and, therefore, can be clearly and directly responsible for them. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . if a major blunder occurred in a department of real importance to Australia-
I presume he means the blunder and not the department-
and if the Minister were unaware of it, that Minister should accept responsibility for the mistakes of his department and offer to resign.

One wonders how much more major a blunder has to be than one which costs the country hundreds of millions of dollars. It was interesting to hear Senator Peter Rae argue strongly in defence of the Attorney-General (Senator Durack), which of course he is entitled to do, when only recently he was particularly angry at certain malfunctions in other departments of this Government, particularly in relation to the Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd matter, which, as I recall, concerned something like only $1m. However, the Prime Minister's attitude to ministerial responsibility has been somewhat flexible or at least it has changed over the years. By 1978 he was arguing that ministerial inability to be supermen should not surprise anyone. Of course we are not asking that. We are not expecting a Minister to know what every twopenny-halfpenny clerk is doing in his department. We do expect him to know what the senior members are doing. Again in 1978 the Prime Minister went on to say:
It is, after all, the very reason for the existence of a Public Service, organised into departments, to act as the Minister's agents.

That brings me back to what Senator Evans said earlier about buck-passing. Where does a lack of awareness stop being an important issue? As far as we on this side of the House are concerned the concept of unawareness being a mitigating factor in a blunder as severe as this is just not good enough. For a start the mind positively boggles at where the argument about ignorance could finish. Of course it gives Ministers who are incompetent, dishonest or just plain stupid the opportunity to plead ignorance even if they were not actually ignorant, and worse, it puts into the hands of senior public servants the incentive not to tell their Ministers what they are doing. That simply is not acceptable. Ignorance is no excuse in most other areas of the law and there is no reason why it should be here. It is interesting to note that the Attorney-General at least had second thoughts about where his responsibility lay, having apparently first thought of resigning but then being reported as saying on 27 August that he had decided against resigning. He stated:
In our system, Ministers don't resign unless there is some personal failing and that isn't the case.

I consider ignorance of one's department in a matter which leads to depleting government coffers of hundreds of millions of dollars some considerable failing, particularly as this was a failing which took place not on one occasion but over some seven years. The mismanagement in the Crown Solicitor's Office is traceable at least to 1973. Investigation by Mr Todman of the Australian Taxation Office into the first known bottom-of-the-harbour scheme took place in that year. In 1975 the Taxation Office instructed the Perth Deputy Crown Solicitor to commence action as soon as possible which it did not do. From 1978 until 1982-as has already been pointed out-Mr O'Sullivan Jnr placed completed instructions in the bottom drawer of his desk and simply left them there to gather dust. At one stage in 1978 the then Crown Solicitor asked for a written report, did not receive one and did not query this failure to produce what he had asked for even though he was in Perth that year. Again in 1978 the Taxation Office raised with the Treasurer (Mr Howard) the possible need for criminal legislation apparently not because it was needed, as Mr Costigan makes clear, but because it was discouraged by the Crown Solicitor's procrastinations, which included the erroneous advice that there was insufficient evidence to establish a case. In 1979 legal officers in the Taxation Office examined the material and could not understand why the existing law was not being used to redress the situation. In 1980 the Attorney-General received a report as a result of the management review undertaken jointly with the Public Service Board, which said of the Crown Solicitor's Office:
. . . the formal structural organization for handling matters has broken down and there are now confused lines of control and uncertainty about who is responsible . . . for particular matters.

The same review disclosed that 38 per cent of files were at least a year in arrears, 21 per cent more than two years behind and 10 per cent three or more years in backlog. The Attorney-General took no action to invoke sections 17, 19 or 25 of the Public Service Act, which do enable a Minister, notwithstanding the secrecy provisions of section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act, to investigate problems. Section 19 in particular empowers the Public Service Board to inter alia:
. . . enter any department . . . summon any person . . . take evidence on oath . . . require the production of documents.

Indeed, as I understand it, the Board's view is that it could and would undertake detailed performance evaluations if requested by the Minister. Apparently no such requests were made by the Attorney-General concerning the problems that were becoming more and more evident, in the seven years since the Fraser Government took office, in some of the Deputy Crown Solicitor's offices. It is unfortunate, but it is inescapable, that the failure of the Attorney- General to ensure efficiency in his Department has led to damage not only in dollar terms but also, and most importantly, to the community's social fabric and respect for law and government and just plain honesty. A recent article in the Australian Financial Review made the point:

Very large numbers of Australians who once accepted that they had a duty to pay taxes, even while grumbling about the amount, now have been confronted with the spectacle of billions of dollars being ripped off by smart operators, legally or not. They see that many people in the highest income groups feel no obligation to pay any taxes at all and have few scruples about arranging their affairs so as to pay little or nothing. And these people include many of the leading figures in our society, in groups commanding considerable respect. Doctors, lawyers, businessmen, accountants have all been in for their cut.

The newspaper did not make the point but apparently knights and television personalities have been in for theirs as well. The Attorney-General must be seen to be responsible for the appalling incompetence in some sections of his Department, if not for its origin, then at least for allowing it to continue. It is my personal belief that the Treasurer, having ignored the advice from two Deputy Commissioners of Taxation that prosecutions could be launched, is also culpable. Some blame also at least lies with the Prime Minister who, having said in 1972 and 1978 that Ministers could not be expected to be aware of all they needed to be aware of in their departments, subsequently did nothing to make their lives any easier or their knowledge any more simple to gain. I think it is appropriate to finish with a comment from another article, this time in the Melbourne Age which, while stating that the record indicates that the Attorney- General is a bad administrator, continues:

while there is still no evidence suggesting he knew what bungling was happening beneath him, a good adminstrator runs a tight department and puts the fear of God into those senior bureaucrats who do the day-to-day supervising.

TALK.START.PARA: —He would not frighten anyone.

—The Attorney-General is a perfectly nice man. That ought not to be held against him as a person. Unfortunately when his niceness precludes his Department from operating efficiently, one suspects that he ought not to have been put in the position in the first place or that he should have been subsequently replaced.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating this afternoon the following matter of public importance put forward by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Button):

SPEECH.PARA: The totally unsatisfactory and inadequate performance of the Attorney-General in relation to the issues raised by the Costigan report.

That is supposed to be the subject. It is undoubtedly phrased that way so that the Opposition can attempt to have a re-run of the unsuccessful attempt a fortnight ago to censure the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) in connection with the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union conducted by Mr Costigan.

The performance of the Attorney-General has been raised in this matter of public importance and this gives me the opportunity to talk about some of the things that the Attorney-General has done. I am quite fascinated to hear someone like Senator Evans-Senator Evans of all people-attacking the Attorney-General in the way that he did today. We in this Senate day after day had to put up with Senator Evans attempting to bludgeon the Attorney-General in relation to the freedom of information legislation. The Attorney-General gave that legislation and Senator Evans's proposals deep consideration and appreciation. He went back to the Cabinet and gained agreement to change certain parts of the legislation. He acted specifically at the request of Senator Evans. Yet Senator Evans stands here today and makes this unwarranted attack on the Attorney-General, an attack totally lacking in substance-a lack of substance which I will come to in due course and which I will establish from the words of Senator Walsh, who sits alongside Senator Evans.

Let us look at the achievements of the Attorney-General. Firstly, he has been involved in off-shore settlement, including the negotiations with the States, the Premiers Conference agreement and the ultimate protection of the Great Barrier Reef. He has been involved with human rights and civil liberties. He established the Human Rights Commission. He was involved in the establishment of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation legislation which implemented the Hope Royal Commission on Intelligence and Security recommendations. He has also been involved in the complaints against police legislation, the Criminal Investigation Bill and the Crimes Currency Act. He is now involved in proposals for a sentencing council. In the field of individuals' rights he was involved with the proclamation of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act which allows appeals to be made by citizens to the Federal Court against decisions of Ministers or bureaucrats on questions of law. I mentioned the freedom of information legislation. He was involved in activities in relation to defamation. In relation to family law, he was involved with the reintroduction of amendments to the family law legislation on the basis of the recommendations of a parliamentary committee which he established. He was also involved in anti- trust arrangements with the United States of America and the introduction of the Foreign Anti-trust Judgments (Restriction of Enforcement) Act. We have that magnificent piece of legislation in relation to statutory interpretation, the Acts Interpretation Act. All sorts of matters have been raised in relation to constitutional reform. The Attorney-General has been involved with legal aid.

All sorts of appointments have been made to the benches of the various courts of the land. Let me mention the number of appointments in which the Attorney- General has been involved. The Attorney-General appointed the Chief Justice of the High Court. No criticism has been made anywhere in Australia on that appointment. He appointed four justices to the High Court of Australia. Again we have heard not one word of criticism. I might add that beforehand all sorts of suggestions were made. In fact one day we sat here and heard Senator Evans say good-bye to the Attorney-General on the basis that before we came back to the Parliament the Attorney-General would be on the High Court. That is what Senator Evans was trying to tell the newspapers of Australia. Of course, he was wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Murphy story.

—That is right, there was the Murphy nonsense. Those things happen on the other side. The Attorney-General appointed four justices to the High Court, again without a word of criticism from anyone. He has appointed ten judges to the Federal Court and eleven judges to the Family Court, again without a word of criticism from any people on the other side.
—For goodness sake, what is he supposed to do-look after the butchers?

—Of course he is doing the right thing. The Attorney-General's conduct has been raised in this supposed matter of public importance and I am pointing out how immaculate has been his conduct in his term of office as Attorney-General. It is about time members of the Opposition recognised that.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me just turn to the subject of this alleged criticism in relation to the handling of so-called tax evasion matters. This Government has done more about tax evasion; this Government has raised the expectations in relation to tax evasion. It has been this Government's actions which have finally brought to the attention of members of the Opposition what the subject has been all about. I can remember standing here and explaining to senators on the other side the problems created by tax evasion and they did not understand what I was talking about. Finally they have worked it all out. Finally it has come through to them. It has done so because this Government set up a royal commission. How can we win ? We set up an investigative body and when the investigative body discloses the sorts of things one would worry about members of the Opposition say: 'Resign'. How can we possibly win? Why do not members of the Opposition read what the Royal Commissioner had to say on these matters? I will quote what he had to say so that it can be recorded in Hansard. At paragraph 128 of Chapter 3 of the report of the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, Mr Costigan said:

In taking action it is necessary to remove some of the substantial obstacles that have deterred action in the past. The most significant deterrent has been the inability of the Taxation Office to act in co-operation with other law enforcement agencies to enforce the law. That inability arises because of section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act. It drops a legislative curtain over the knowledge gained by the Taxation Office of the fraud. It impedes investigations. It inhibits redress. Indeed, from my observations the prohibition of section 16 is magnified in the minds of Officers of the Taxation Office so as to give it even greater breadth than it has . . . This should not be allowed to continue.
Then at paragraph 132 of Chapter 3 he says:

It is essential that the Treasurer of the Commonwealth of Australia should be able to gain full access to taxation information so that he can see the extent to which the Revenue of the Commonwealth may be being affected by fiscal policy, or by the depredations of thieves and rogues. Should any Treasurer in the future seek to misuse the access to information that this would give him, the matter may be redressed by Parliament, and if not by Parliament, by the people at an election. Likewise, the Attorney-General should have free access to all information that comes to the Crown Solicitor's Office, and not be inhibited by the operations of section 16.

I will say this about Senator Walsh: It is clear to me from Senator Walsh's questions in this Senate that he understands that the paragraphs I have just quoted in fact make sure that the Attorney-General should be free of criticism. Senator Walsh has turned his vitriol to one particular period. He claims the period was three weeks but in fact it was 15 days. That is all that Senator Walsh has criticised. What he says is that the Attorney-General stands condemned because for 15 days after the report was received he took no action.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, he left the crooks in charge of the files.

—That is right. Senator Walsh confirms what I have been saying. He said: He left the crooks in charge of the files for 15 days. That is Senator Walsh's criticism. Everyone acknowledges that Senator Walsh understands the significance of these things. So we narrow his criticism down to an allegation that for a period of 15 days the Attorney-General failed to act. That was from 3 August until 18 August. Let me just point out that in a period of 15 days the Department, not just the Attorney-General, had to analyse the report of Mr Costigan, then investigate what evidence was available to support the findings of Mr Costigan and then make a recommendation not to the Attorney-General but to the permanent head because suspension in fact is carried out not by the Attorney -General but by the permanent head. So Senator Walsh has now learned another thing which may interest him, that in fact the Attorney-General is not responsible for the suspension; the permanent head is responsible. So that, Senator Walsh, in your own words, proves conclusively the innocence of the Attorney-General and I say-
—Order! The honourable senator will address the Chair.

—I certainly will address the Chair. I will say to you, Mr Deputy President, that the Australian Labor Party is playing politics in this matter. It is about time that the Opposition stopped playing politics and engaging in mud-slinging and started to assist this Parliament to demonstrate some leadership to the Australian people. When one listens to the nonsense that we have had to put up with again today-we had to put up with it a week ago-is it any wonder that in particular the young people of Australia are absolutely fed up with politics and politicians? I suggest that it is about time the Senate got down to discussing some of the real issues which are of concern to the people of Australia today. For example, in a question of mine today I mentioned the problems of drought and how we may look after the people of this country who are suffering from those problems. These are national matters which are of vital importance.
—The Budget, and all of those things.

—As my colleague Senator Teague says, we have not had a chance to have a proper analysis of the Budget. Glory be, are we going to put up with this mud-slinging politics for the whole of this session or are we to be allowed to run the Parliament in the way it ought to be run to give some leadership to the people of Australia? I move:

The document read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Customs Act 1901 and the Excise Act 1901 in a number of respects. The main amendments proposed by the Bill deal with the levels of penalty for Customs offences. Other amendments are directed at controls over the unloading and handling of cargo, the licensing of depots for short-term holding of goods, the entering of goods and duty exemptions on ships' and aircraft's stores.

I would point out to honourable senators that amendments were also made in the other place to incorporate into this Bill provisions specifically directed at controlling the sale and delivery of duty-free goods to intending travellers from duty-free shops operating outside airports.

The Report of the Australian Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs pointed out inadequacies in the penalties for breaches of the Customs Act. Other inadequacies in Customs Act penalties were highlighted last year in the context of offences committed in the unlawful exportation of horse and kangaroo meat to the United States. As part of the Government's response to those issues, a general review of Customs Act penalties has been undertaken in consultation with the Government's legal advisers. The review took into consideration matters to which I have just referred, the difficulties faced by Customs in supervising the growing flow of goods into and out of Australia, the need for Customs to rely to a significant degree on the integrity of importers and exporters and the magnitude of the rewards that can be obtained from revenue evasion or unlawful import or export activities. It was concluded that the levels of penalties for most non-narcotics Customs offences should be substantially increased.

The Bill proposes that the penalty for revenue related offences should be up to five times the amount sought to be evaded and not less than two times that amount. For the offences of importing prohibited imports or exporting prohibited exports a maximum penalty equivalent to three times the value of the goods is proposed.
Where the amount evaded or the value of the goods cannot be ascertained, however, it is proposed that a maximum penalty of $50,000 should apply.
It is further proposed that this maximum of $50,000 should also be the prescribed penalty for other offences which strike at the very basis of Customs control.

Included in this category are offences such as failure by the master of a ship to permit his ship to be boarded or by the pilot of an aircraft to land for boarding, breach of conditions to which any permitted movement of goods under Customs control may be subject in particularly high risk situations and the unlawful interference with containers or goods between the time of landing and their clearance by Customs.

In respect of some offences which, while serious, are not amongst the most important, a maximum penalty of $25,000 is proposed. Examples of such offences are the unloading without permission of imported cargo or cargo that has been loaded for export.

A maximum penalty of $10,000 is proposed for offences such as failing to comply with conditions to which certain permissions for the importation, exportation or movement of goods is subject and for other offences of equal seriousness.

Other proposed maximum penalties include $5,000 for offences such as interfering with Customs seals, $2,000 for offences such as the failure to deliver up imported goods that have been washed ashore or salvaged , and $1,000 for offences such as the failure to furnish export returns and the failure by licensees of warehouses and owners of warehoused goods to observe certain requirements in relation to facilities and documentation.

No action is proposed by this Bill in relation to penalties for narcotics offences punishable under section 235 of the Customs Act. Those penalties were reviewed and substantially increased by amendments to the Act in 1977 and 1979.

The proposed penalty increases require consequential adjustments to ensure that Customs prosecutions may be brought in an appropriate court. At present the Act provides that prosecutions involving a pecuniary penalty not exceeding $1,000 may be instituted in courts of summary jurisdiction or in intermediate courts.

In order to allow the increased penalties to be recovered without having to institute comparatively minor prosecutions at the Supreme Court level, greater use is to be made of the existing intermediate level of courts by increasing their jurisdictional level to $20,000. The jurisdictional level of courts of summary jurisdiction is to be increased to $5,000.

Other amendments will extend the present system of dealing administratively with relatively minor offences committed by arriving international passengers or crew. It is proposed that the system of administrative settlement should apply also to offences committed by other persons which could lead to forfeiture of goods and where the duty evaded is $500 or less.

The Bill also proposes amendments to provisions governing the lodgment and processing of entries of goods for home consumption. The changes simplify, update and remedy defects in the existing provisions.

It is proposed that entries for goods lodged with a Collector before the arrival of the carrying ship or aircraft at its first port or airport of call in Australia will become effective for duty purposes on the arrival of the ship or aircraft at that first port or airport. Presently, advance entries are not effective until the goods actually arrive at the port or airport to which they have been consigned. This requirement has given rise to anomalous situations where identical goods may attract different rates of duty depending on the time of arrival of the carrying ship at various Australian ports. Delays in a ship's movements around Australia may also prevent some of a shipment of identical goods on the same vessel which are discharged at different ports, being entered in time to meet deadlines applying under import quota arrangements.
Other amendments are proposed to clarify administrative aspects of the lodgment and withdrawal of entries.

A further important amendment is the proposed inclusion of a new Part VA in the Act to introduce a new system of licensing of places used as depots for holding imported goods and goods for export prior to their examination by Customs.

In view of the similarity of operation of premises used for the long term warehousing of goods subject to Customs control and the short term holding of goods for examination in depots, the licensing scheme proposed in the Bill is modelled directly on that now applying in respect of warehouses.

The proposed new depot licensing provisions set out criteria under which licences may be granted and provide authority for the imposition of conditions, the charging of fees and the exercise of certain disciplinary powers in the event of a breach of the terms of a licence.

The Bill also proposes amendment of the provisions in the Act dealing with the report, unshipment, placement and movement of imported cargo. These amendments will correct deficiencies in the existing provisions which fail to accommodate modern cargo handling procedures, particularly in relation to containerised cargo.

Minor changes are proposed to be made to provisions covering the licensing of Customs warehouses and Customs agents. These changes are designed to overcome administrative difficulties in operating these schemes.
I now turn to the amendments that were inserted into the Bill in the other place.

Since the inception of duty-free shops, the general authorities in section 40AA of the Customs Act and section 61A of the Excise Act, which allow permissions to be granted for the movement of goods whilst the goods remain under Customs control, have been relied upon to enable duty-free operators to conduct their business at places outside airports. Permissions granted under these sections contained specified conditions to ensure the exportation of the goods. A breach of any condition rendered the shop proprietor liable for any duty on goods not exported.

Legal advice has been received that these provisions do not provide the necessary authority for Customs to impose, on shop proprietors and on purchasers , conditions which require that duty-free goods sold to travellers be exported.

The amendments proposed in effect restate, on a valid legal basis, the conditions presently applied to permissions. These conditions place obligations on the shop proprietors to make travellers aware of the conditions with which they are required to comply, to keep records and furnish returns, to produce satisfactory proof of export of goods and to accept liability for payment of duty on goods in respect of which satisfactory proof of export is not produced.
The proposed amendments will not affect the present day-to-day operations of the duty-free industry as no change in the procedures at present being followed is envisaged.

Because duty-free shops have the status of being warehouses licensed for the purposes of the Customs Act, other provisions of a more general nature which are included in Part V of the Customs Act also have application in relation to the operation and control of these stores.

In response to representations made by the duty-free industry, the Bill provides for all administrative decisions made pursuant to the proposed new provisions to be able to be reviewed by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.
Finally, the Bill proposes amendments to clarify the duty exemptions applicable to stores for use in ships and aircraft.

These amendments have equal application to both the Customs Act and the Excise Act and are designed to ensure that the duty exemptions only apply in respect of ships and aircraft engaged on international voyages or flights.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

The Remuneration Tribunal's 1982 Review was presented to the Senate on 26 August 1982. Honourable senators will by now be aware that the Government has accepted the Tribunal's recommendations and determinations.

In making its review, the Tribunal took into account the state of the national economy, and within proper limits, the effects which its decision may have on it . It gave careful consideration to the matters raised by the Prime Minister and the Treasurer concerning the necessity to achieve a moderation of the rate of wage and salary increases in the community in order to avoid an immediate rise in unemployment, to reduce inflationary pressures and to avoid further damage to our international competitiveness. The Tribunal was persuaded that exceptional circumstances exist and consequently made determinations and recommendations based on a general level of increase in salaries of 7 per cent. Remuneration directed at the reimbursement of outgoings and expenditure, for example Electorate Allowance and Travelling Allowance, has been adjusted according to the Tribunal's assessment of what is necessary to achieve a proper reimbursement . It would be inequitable for persons within the Tribunal's jurisdiction to suffer a penalty in respect of expenditure made by them in carrying out their duties and responsibilities.

The Remuneration Tribunal's willingness to consider the national interest gives a clear lead to other wage-fixing bodies. The Government hopes that wage-fixing bodies throughout Australia will also be prepared to consider the wider ramifications of their decisions. At a time when wage rises are pricing people out of a tight labour market, wage-fixing authorities have a responsibility to take into account the economic climate in which they operate.

In accepting the Remuneration Tribunal's determinations, the Government has also sought to give a lead. Honourable senators will be aware that there is considerable public support for the proposition that Parliamentarians should ' practise what they preach' with regard to wage restraint.

The Government is greatly encouraged by decisions already taken by a number of large Australian companies to restrain increases in salaries. If the example set by the Government is followed by other employers and accepted by wage and salary earners generally, it will play an important part in achieving the levels of wage restraint that Australia needs.
I turn now to the Remuneration and Allowances Amendment Bill 1982.
Part 11 of the Bill implements the recommendations of the Remuneration Tribunal in relation to the salaries and allowances of the Judiciary.

I draw particular attention to Clause 6 of the Bill which changes the eligibility for the ''Canberra allowance'' payable to Justices of the High Court . The Act as it stands provides for an annual allowance to be payable to a Justice of the High Court who held office on 1 July 1980 and who has continued to have his sole or principal place of residence outside Canberra. The allowance is not payable to a Justice who has his sole or principal place of residence in Canberra or to a Justice appointed after 1 July 1980.

In its 1981 and 1982 reviews, the Remuneration Tribunal recommended that the limitation to Justices appointed before 1 July 1980 should be removed. The Government has looked at the matter again in the light of the Tribunal's views and representations which it has received on this subject. The State Governments , especially those of the less populous States, have been strongly of the view that the Justices should not all be compelled to live in Canberra. The argument runs that Justices who continue to live in their home States will keep in touch with the shades of thought and attitude around the nation which help the High Court in tune with the federal nature of Australia. The representations have come not only from the States but also from the Law Council, from bodies representing the legal profession and from individual members of the legal profession.

In the light of these expressions of opinion, the Government now believes that it would be appropriate to adopt the recommendation of the Remuneration Tribunal and to remove the bar to the payment of the ''Canberra allowance'' to High Court Justices appointed after 1 July 1980 who choose to retain their sole or principal place of residence outside Canberra.
It is not intended that the allowance be payable to Justices who take up residence in Canberra, or to a Justice who, having taken up residence in Canberra, then decides to return to live elsewhere.

Part III of the Bill proposes to amend the Ministers of State Act 1952 by increasing the annual sum appropriated for Ministerial salaries to enable the increases recommended by the Tribunal to be payable. It is proposed to increase this sum from $452,000 to $575,000.
The opportunity has also been taken to propose certain amendments to the Remuneration Tribunals Act 1973 which are unrelated to the Tribunal's Review.

The first of these amendments is designed to remove Northern Territory and Norfolk Island public offices and members of the National Aboriginal Conference from the scope of the appropriation provisions of the Act. It is not appropriate , nor was it ever intended, that payments to the holders of these public offices be made from the Commonwealth Consolidated Revenue Fund, but rather that the responsible governments and the Conference respectively should provide the funds required.

The Bill also proposes to empower the Norfolk Island Legislative Assembly to disallow determinations by the Tribunal in respect of its members. This power currently lies with the Commonwealth Parliament, but it is considered to be more appropriately a matter for the assembly. The disallowance power would not extend to variation of the Tribunal's determinations.

It is also proposed to bring within the provisions of sub-section 7 (11) of the Act the office of member of the National Aboriginal Conference. The effect of this amendment would be to treat members of the Conference in the same way as full-time Commonwealth employees. Sub-section 7 (11) provides that full-time Commonwealth employees are not entitled to receive remuneration in respect of a part-time public office unless a specific exemption is made by regulation. A further minor amendment proposed in respect of the National Aboriginal Conference is that it will now be included within the Act as a body the offices of which are within the Tribunal's jurisdiction. This has previously been achieved by regulation and the proposed amendment is of a machinery nature only.

Finally, the Bill seeks to extend the Tribunal's jurisdiction with respect to certain Commonwealth-owned or controlled companies. The employees of Commonwealth companies limited by guarantee have been outside the Tribunal's jurisdiction but there is no reason why this should be so and it is now proposed that they be included. Few such offices are involved and existing arrangements would not be upset by the amendment as it would only make it possible for such offices to be referred to the Tribunal in terms of a specific request.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.

DEBATE.TITLE: WILDLIFE PROTECTION (REGULATION OF EXPORTS AND IMPORTS) BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to strengthen arrangements for the protection of Australia's animals and plants, and world wildlife generally; by improving the effectiveness of our import and export controls.

The uniqueness of Australia's flora and fauna places a special responsibility on all of us to ensure that we do our utmost to avoid species becoming extinct. Regrettably, many species of our flora and fauna have become extinct in recent times. The causes include thoughtlessness, over-exploitation and simple lack of knowledge and understanding. Possibly the most devastating impact has been through the destruction of natural habitat, which for many species has made survival impossible.

Over the years there has been a steadily increasing public concern about wildlife protection. Governments have responded with a range of legislative and administrative measures. Australia has traditionally set high standards of protection, and in some respects we have provided world leadership. Nonetheless the Government believes that continuing vigilance is necessary, particularly to strengthen existing arrangements wherever possible.

The actions of non-government organisations and individual Australians obviously are most important in protecting our wildlife. Governments must also help by providing factual information, in educational activities and in developing and implementing appropriate legislation. In this context I would like to refer to some recent initiatives.
Commonwealth Nature Conservation Activities

We are supporting the Australian Biological Resources Study which will ultimately provide full descriptions and classifications of Australian plants and animals, as well as identifying their distributions. The Bureau of Flora and Fauna within my Department has completed the first three volumes of the Flora of Australia. It is well advanced with the Australian Plant Name Index. The first volume of the Zoological Catalogue of Australia has also been completed.

The Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service continues to provide the Government with advice relating to wildlife and nature protection. The Service participates in planning the implementation of wildlife protection measures in co-operation with relevant State, Territorial and Commonwealth Authorities. It supports an extensive program of research about Australian wildlife, and contributes significantly to conservation awareness through its publication program.

The Great Barrier Reef Region contains an enormous variety of living species. Three Sections of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park have now been declared. Work is proceeding systematically towards the progressive declaration of further sections. Park management work has commenced in the Capricornia Section, with full collaboration between the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority and the Queensland National Parks and Wildlife Service. The public has been invited to participate in the preparation of the zoning plans for the Cairns and Cormorant Pass Sections.

Important nature conservation areas throughout Australia have been entered on the Register of the National Estate, which is maintained by the Australian Heritage Commission. Recently the Great Barrier Reef, Kakadu National Park and the Willandra Lakes region were entered on the World Heritage List.
CSIRO plays a vital role in the protection of our wildlife through the wide ranging research activities of the Biological Institute and the Earth Resources Institute.

A particularly significant legislative achievement in 1980 was the enactment of the Whale Protection Act, which prohibits the taking of cetaceans in Australian waters, or by Australians elsewhere. At meetings of the International Whaling Commission, Australia continues to play a most significant role in reducing the catch quotas, and in arguing for a complete moratorium on harvesting.

Whilst I have outlined some Commonwealth activities on nature conservation, honourable senators will be well aware of the many important activities of the States and Territories in the protection of wildlife, and the strong collaboration between all governments through the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers.

International Trade The protection of wildlife has a dimension, which extends beyond our own shores. In recognition of its international obligations, Australia is party to a number of nature conservation treaties and agreements. One is the Migratory Birds Agreement with Japan which provides for the protection of many species of migratory birds, and for associated research. Australia was the first nation to accede to the Convention on Wetlands of International Importance under which Kakadu National Park is listed. We were also the first to ratify the Convention for the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources.

Despite the efforts of nations upholding the provisions of international conventions, there is a flourishing illicit trade in wildlife. This trade contributes considerably towards the extinction of numerous species. Some idea of the commercial pressures may be gained from the payments involved. $50,000 may be paid for a coat from the skin of the ocelot, or the rare snow leopard. Pairs of live Australian parrots have been sold for up to $10,000 overseas.

Another dimension to this illegal trade is the appalling cruelty and wildlife losses involved. The extraordinary measures taken by smugglers to conceal wildlife in transit impose much suffering and injury to the creatures involved. The actual death rate among smuggled birds can be as high as 90 per cent.

None-the-less the ease of international travel and the lure of high profits, provides a strong temptation to many people to participate in this distasteful trade. The uniqueness of Australian wildlife continues to provide ready markets overseas.

CITES In 1973, Australia and about 70 countries negotiated the Convention on Internationl Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora. The Convention is commonly known as CITES. It arose from world wide concern about the adverse effects of unregulated trade on the world's wildlife. Australia ratified CITES in 1976, upon promulgation of the Customs (Endangered Species) Regulations. These regulations and the Prohibited Imports and Prohibited Exports Regulations under the Customs Act, and various Acts and Ordinances relating to Australia's external Territories, provide the present legislative basis for the control of overseas trade in wildlife.

The New Legislation The Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Bill consolidates wildlife trade controls into a single Act, and allows the Commonwealth to more effectively implement the objects of CITES.

The Bill is structured around seven Schedules of species in which trade is prohibited or regulated. A permit system will be used to impose conditions appropriate to the status of the species being traded. The Bill provides for maximum penalties of $100,000 or five years imprisonment, plus forfeiture of goods and equipment involved in the case of individuals. The maximum penalty is $200,000 plus forfeiture in the case of organisations. These penalties are appropriate to the high potential rewards involved, and to indications of organised criminal activity in wildlife trafficking. The possibility of a jail sentence is a necessary deterrent, as illegal traffickers customarily offer to pay fines and all other expenses for couriers.

The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation found, in its 1976 report on Trafficking in Fauna, that wildlife smuggling occurs in remote areas of Australia. As it is extremely difficult to apprehend persons in the act of illegal smuggling in remote areas, and because it is not possible to prevent all illegal imports through points of entry to Australia, the Bill provides for possession of illegally imported wildlife to be an offence . Similarly, the Bill provides for enforcement officers to have powers of arrest , search and seizure appropriate to the difficult circumstances and isolated areas in which the Bill must be enforced.

State and Territory Consultation During preparation of the legislation detailed discussions were held with the relevant State and Territory authorities. These discussions have been particularly helpful in improving the drafting of the Bill . I note also that there has been widespread support by State Conservation Ministers for the Commonwealth to legislate so as to improve the regulation of the international trade in wildlife and wildlife products. Under the Bill, the Minister is required to ensure that the States and Territories continue to be properly consulted on a range of matters where they would have a particular interest-for example, in relation to any amendment to the Schedules which could affect Australian wildlife. It is noteworthy that consultation through the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers and other bodies will be necessary for proper implementation of various parts of the legislation.

Strict Controls I believe it is important to note that the Bill does not lessen in any way the stance Australia has taken in the past on wildlife protection, either in Australia or overseas. Regarding Australian wildlife and related products, the Bill is based on the premise that commercial trade will only be permitted if it has been conclusively established that such trade will not adversely affect Australian wildlife. There will be no weakening of the strict controls that Australia has traditionally maintained on the export of native fauna. The Bill further extends this protection to our unique native flora.

It is also important to emphasise that normal commercial trade in agricultural, forestry and fisheries products will not be affected by the Bill. There will be no barrier to the import of presently permitted live aquarium fish. The Bill permits trade between bona-fide zoos and scientific institutions. There is also provision for individuals to become affiliated with scientific institutions for the purposes of research.

Schedules 1 and 2 of the Bill protect endangered wildlife, and wildlife that would be threatened by continuation of unregulated trade. The listings of species and populations of species, in these two Schedules are derived mainly from Appendices I and II to CITES. Further Australian species that are considered to be threatened with extinction have been added to Schedule 1. Trade in Schedule 1 species is limited to that undertaken for scientific purposes, by bona-fide zoos or for commercial trade in captive bred or artificially propagated specimens. Schedule 2 is less stringent in that specimens taken from the wild can be traded commercially if they are taken under an approved management program.

Schedule 3 allows for the regulation of trade in wildlife requiring special protection on grounds such as animal welfare, or to reflect other needs for stringent controls, including those applied by other countries. Trade in Schedule 3 species is only permitted in exceptional circumstances by bona-fide zoos or for scientific purposes.
Schedule 4 lists those commercial species of Australian flora and fauna that are currently exported and for which a permit will not be required.

Schedules 5 and 6 provide for the import of live animals and plants such as farm animals, table birds and fish. These Schedules enable Australian wildlife and its habitat to be protected by preventing the introduction of live animals and plants that could adversely affect the Australian natural environment. Examples of species which have been introduced in the past, and have seriously affected the Australian environment, include rabbits and lantana.
Schedule 7 lists those species of native animals eligible to be treated as household pets for export under strict conditions.
Schedule 8 is the text of CITES.

Administration The Bill places responsibility for the policy aspects of regulation of trade in wildlife with the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. Administration of the Bill will be undertaken by the Director of National Parks and Wildlife and enforcement will continue to be by the Bureau of Customs and the Australian Federal Police. In line with current practice, the Minister will be able to make arrangements with the States and Territories on various aspects of the Bill, including enforcement by State police forces and wildlife officers.

Mr President, while there are people who argue that nature conservation is a lost cause, beaten by our uncaring and greedy world, I believe it is a cause we can win and are winning. This Bill is a major piece of legislation reinforcing other Government measures developed to conserve Australian fauna and flora, and to ensure that international trade in threatened wildlife is responsibly controlled. It implements a number of the recommendations of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation which reported in 1976 on Trafficking in Fauna. The Bill does not interfere with legitimate commercial trade and it provides for the specialised requirements of science. It provides appropriate penalties to deter those who would profit by illegal trafficking in wildlife. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
