The Bills were read a third time in the House of Representatives on 22 April 1982 and subsequently introduced into the Senate on 27 April 1982. There are two main issues in this report. One deals with the legal aspects of the legislation and the other with its philosophy and practical ramifications for Australian industrial relations. Because both these aspects are complex and some matters have yet to be resolved, the Committee considers that more time is required to bring up a comprehensive final report and to enable the Committee to reach a final conclusive view on many of the issues.
Paragraph 2.9, at page 7 of the report, states:

The majority of witnesses (including those representing many of the employer groups) expressed the opinion that the major purposes which the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill 1982 and the Commonwealth Employees (Voluntary Membership of Unions) Bill 1982 are meant to achieve would, in a variety of ways , further disturb the currently unsettled industrial relations climate and would not contribute to industrial peace. The Committee has formed no concluded view on these submissions but, because of their significance in relation to the Committee's terms of reference, wishes to note them at this stage and advise the Senate that it requires further time to evaluate the complex issues which are involved.

The Committee, during its deliberations became aware that a majority of witnesses, persons and organisations making submissions did not favour the legislation. Nevertheless the Committee concluded that it should not be persuaded by majority opinion but should look at the legislation and its intentions on their merits before forming a conclusion. It has become apparent during the inquiry that even organisations which could not be expected to take public issue with the philosophical orientation of the Bills nevertheless felt the need to draw the attention of the Committee to practical difficulties in the implementation and consequences of the legislation. For example, the Confederation of Australian Industry, in the conclusion to its submissions, told the Committee:

As indicated throughout this submission, CAI supports the provisions of the Bill which are the subject of the Select Committee's Terms of Reference, while recognising that in some respects difficulties of practical implementation will arise.

Other organisations of employers which have made written submissions to the Committee but have not given public evidence have expressed similar reservations . Significant legal issues having been raised, the Committee sought the assistance of the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations and the Attorney-General's Department in respect of this evidence. The evidence of the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations was not helpful on these matters, and the evidence of the Attorney-General's Department was even less helpful. The legal doubts that had been raised were not dispelled by the answers provided by these Departments to the Committee's questions. Subsequently the Committee directed specific written questions to the Attorney-General.
They are contained in Appendix 5 of the report. Paragraph 2.7 continues:

The responses by the Attorney-General are regarded as being particularly unhelpful, indicating an unwillingness or an inability to answer a number of doubts raised in the evidence relating to the legal ramifications and practical consequences of the Bills.

An indication of the other technical and legal questions which the Committee considered should be answered is the list of questions forwarded to the Attorney -General (Senator Durack) and shown on page 45 of the Committee's report. The Committee attempted to find out, as a result of the evidence of Mr Macken, whether Mr Macken's submissions were substantially correct and whether his view of what would happen if the legislation were passed was correct or was considered during the development of the legislation. The Committee also wanted to pursue a number of other technical and legal questions regarding the legislation which only the Government was able to answer. These related to the intent of the legislation, the regulation making power in the legislation-which would be of particular interest to a number of honourable senators on both sides of the chamber-the protection of the legal rights of the individual under the law and so on. At no stage did the Committee get full, open and frank answers from the Attorney-General's Department and the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations on these questions.

One can conclude from an examination of the public evidence that what happened was that the officers of the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations shifted responsibility for the legal aspects of the Bill on to the Attorney- General's Department. The Attorney-General's Department then nominated an officer to appear before the Committee. In answer to a question, that officer stated that he had nothing to do with the drafting of the legislation and was not consulted in relation to the drafting of it. Finally, the Committee resolved to send a list of written questions to the Attorney-General. That list appears at page 45 of the interim report. This is absolutely no reflection at all on the officer of the Attorney-General's Department who appeared before the Committee. He was sent by the Attorney-General's Department and, as he stated, he had had nothing to do with the drafting of the legislation and was not consulted about the drafting of it. The list on page 45 of the report gives an indication of some of the questions the Committee thought should be answered to enable it to carry out properly the task the Senate had given it.

With the benefit of hindsight, it is now safe to say that the Attorney-General was asked these questions when he was preoccupied with matters not connected with the Committee's inquiry. His responses to the Committee's questions appear at page 49 of the interim report and can now be viewed in light of the circumstances to which I have just alluded. Furthermore, the Attorney-General said that questions four to six related to how the Bill would operate in particular situations that may occur and advised that 'the policy aspects involved should be taken up with the sponsors of the Bill if that has not already been done'. The extent to which the Attorney-General's responses to the Committee are unsatisfactory has to be seen against the question of who should take responsibility for answering questions relating to these Bills. The Committee has not received satisfactory answers from the two departments it has questioned and perhaps, given the workings of the bureaucracy, another department-the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet-should have been asked to assist the Committee if, as may well have been the case, it had more to do with the development of this legislation than either of the two departments which the Committee has already questioned.

What is clear at present is that neither the Government departments nor the Government itself are rushing forward to volunteer to defend or explain this legislation, nor do any departments appear to want to take responsibility for it . In pursuing these questions the Committee was not attempting to identify who or what department was responsible for the legislation, nor was it looking for a scapegoat. It was pursuing this course for no other reason than to get some explanation of the intent of the legislation and how that legislation would operate in practice. As things now stand, it still has not received those explanations. The list of unanswered questions can be worked out by anybody interested, from a reading of the appendices to the Committee's report. In brief , on the basis of the information before it, the Committee came to the conclusion, also outlined on page 7, as follows:

The Committee considers that significant deficiencies appear to exist in the legislation so that even if the purposes for which the legislation was formulated were acceptable to the Senate, it could introduce into the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904 inherent inconsistencies and further, could produce a number of consequences which could negate certain purposes for which it was drafted.

As to whether the purposes for which the legislation was drafted are acceptable, that is another question. The views of the majority of witnesses, including those representing many employer groups, that these purposes would not contribute to industrial peace, have been noted by the Committee, which now requires further time to evaluate the complex issues involved before submitting its final report. DEBATE.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION ON THE ACTIVITIES OF THE FEDERATED SHIP PAINTERS AND DOCKERS UNION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement on behalf of the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) on Interim Report No. 4 of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. In seeking leave I should perhaps say that this document has only just come to hand from the Government Printer. It has only recently, therefore, come into the hands of the Opposition. Normally, of course- -
—You're not kidding.

—The Opposition seeks to object. I would have to check with the Attorney whether he wishes to pursue the matter. I think the wish of the Government would be to put the document on the table. I am simply acknowledging that because it has just come from the Printer it has not been in the hands of the Opposition for the normal two hours-a matter which I regret. I wanted the reason to be on the record.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Interim Report No. 4 of the Costigan Royal Commission consisted of three volumes, only Volume 1 of which was recommended by the Commission for publication. However, the Government is firmly of the view that as much as possible of this report should be published. Mr Costigan wrote to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) on 6 September 1982 in response to requests from both the Commonwealth and Victorian governments that he examine whether more of the contents of his report could be published. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard his letter which further explains his reasons for advising against publication of certain parts of his report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
ROYAL COMMISSION ON THE ACTIVITIES OF THE FEDERATED SHIP PAINTERS AND DOCKERS UNION
Commissioner: Mr F. X. Costigan, Q.C. G.P.O. Box 262C, Melbourne, 3001 Secretary : Mr G. Hutton Telephone: (03) 529 2244 6 September, 1982 The Rt Hon. Malcolm Fraser, C.H., M.P.,
Prime Minister,
Parliament House,
CANBERRA, A.C.T. 2600
My dear Prime Minister,

Both the Commonwealth and the Victorian Governments have inquired whether I would modify the recommendation contained in Interim Report No. 4 that Volumes 2 and 3 of that Report should remain confidential. In making that inquiry it has been suggested that I also consider whether, in the event that I remain of the same opinion that the Report should not be tabled, it would be possible for a summary of these two volumes to be published.
To meet this inquiry I have re-read with care both volumes.

With one modification, which I shall refer to shortly, it is still my firm view that these volumes should not be published. The events of the last fortnight have strengthened this view. Moreover any summary of the volumes would be rendered meaningless by the need for massive editing and deletion.
Some of the reasons for this view can be stated (others cannot because the reasons would themselves reveal confidential information):

(a) The reports deal with matters which are the subject of current investigation by the Commission. To reveal the nature and direction of those investigations would be counter-productive to the work of the Commission;

(b) A number of the matters referred to in the two volumes are the subject of proposed or current investigation by law enforcement agencies, some of which have commenced as a direct result of matters ascertained by this Commission. Those investigations, as much as the Commission's investigations, would be prejudiced by the publication of what is presently known;

(c) It is in the interests of the community that the persons mentioned in the two volumes be dealt with according to law and by the implementation of the normal criminal processes. A fair and proper trial would be impossible should the reports be published. In expressing this view, which I have always held, I find considerable support in the observations of several Judges of the High Court in the recent decision in Hammond v. Woodward.

I can see why there is some concern about not publishing these volumes. This springs from the fact that it is public knowledge that the two volumes are in existence and a good deal of speculation has arisen as to their contents, much of it quite unfair to some persons and organisations. It would be quite inaccurate to draw any specific inference as to what names might appear in those volumes, or whether they come from any particular state or territory or country or have associations with any political organisation or group.

I think I should say something about the nature and role of interim reports. Particularly in a Commission such a this, which extends over a considerable period of time and covers a vast range of subjects, it is important that from time to time Government should be informed as to the directions in which the Commission is moving and the conclusions it is reaching on specific matters. Indeed it was contemplated that I should do so when I received a major extension of time in early 1981. By being appraised as to these matters in detail Governments may better determine such legislative and administrative initiatives as may be required. For example, there is currently discussion in the highest places concerning the need or otherwise for a Crime Commission. I believe the confidential volumes can be of assistance in these discussions by revealing the type and character of organised crime in our community and identifying means of suppressing it. For such reports to be useful generalities are not adequate: without detailed analysis their value is limited. But, for the reasons given above, unless such analysis remains confidential it cannot be included in a report.

The modification I referred to in paragraph 3 above relates to Chapter 10 of the Report contained in Volume 2. Following a request transmitted to me by the Commonwealth Attorney-General's Department I have prepared an edited version of this Chapter which I have forwarded to both Governments. It may assist State Attorneys-General and Police Ministers in their current consideration of a Crime Commission. It is for both Governments to determine whether it should be so distributed or whether the publication should be wider.
I have written in similar terms to the Premier of Victoria.
Yours sincerely, Frank Costigan Royal Commissioner

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate again. The Royal Commissioner, however, provided an edited version of chapter 10 suitable for publication. These amendments were minor in nature to prevent individuals being identified. Chapter 10 deals with criminal organisation within the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union and addresses the strategies which might be adopted to combat organised crime. In this regard the Commonwealth would see the proposed National Crimes Commission as being the appropriate body to pursue the fight against organised crime. This chapter contains very significant material including certain general conclusions of the Commission that would be of interest and a source of enlightenment to the general community if generally available. I therefore table the revised version of chapter 10. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate, in accordance with the provisions of the Parliamentary Papers Act 1908, authorise the publication of chapter 10 as edited of the Interim Report No. 4 of the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I wish to make some remarks on the paper and the accompanying statement. First, there is a serious objection from the Opposition both to the timing of the tabling of this paper and to the adequacy of the documentation involved. On the question of timing, Senator Chaney has already stated that the printed document has been in the Government's hands for only a matter of minutes. Certainly it has been in my hands for a matter of only 10 minutes or, at the most, 15 minutes , which has barely given me time to turn the pages of the document let alone to absorb fully the conclusions and contents that are there set out. There was, however, little point in objecting to the tabling of this document at this stage because undoubtedly it was the Government's intention to table the paper in the other place today. That at least gives us some opportunity to have the document circulated to us in the Senate and to make at least some initial response to it.

I have made the point, I hope clearly enough, that the non-refusal of leave is not to be taken as assent to the circumstances in which the document has been tabled. I further make the point, so far as timing is concerned, that it is obviously a ploy by the Government to table this particular document with this great flurry of urgent activity today in order to take the gloss off what has been, by all accounts, a very humiliating experience for the Government in the other place today in the context of the censure motion and what, it might not become me to say, was a humiliating experience for the Government with the matter of public importance in the Senate today, but which nonetheless demonstrated again the pitiful incapacity of the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) to appreciate the nature of his responsibilities.

Obviously, the subject matter of the document which has just been tabled is of enormous public interest. I will come to that in a moment. Obviously it will command a good deal of media space tomorrow. Equally obviously that space will, at least to some extent, be at the expense of the reporting of the Government's humiliation in this Parliament today. I find it a cynical act on the part of the Government, at such short notice and with so little obvious need for that degree of haste, to put the document down in the way that it has. The second point I make is as to the adequacy of the material presented. We have not-

TALK.START.PARA: —Except we have all night to study it. We are on air tomorrow and we have control of the Senate.

—Maybe so. At a later stage I will seek leave to continue my remarks and I will finish what I have to say tomorrow. But there are three or four things that I do wish quite quickly to say now although I appreciate the force of the point made by the honourable senator.
—I am glad you appreciate it because it suggests what you have been saying is nonsense.

—I do not think that will be so, Senator Chaney, because some of us do have a greater capacity than others to absorb the nub of the document, even if only in 15 minutes. It is as to those matters that I want to say something briefly. The second matter which shrieks out at one from the document is how inadequate it is in terms of its coverage of the range of matters which are clearly in the missing volumes 2 and 3 of Interim Report No. 4.

SPEECH.PARA: The paper before us is simply an edited version of one chapter of those missing volumes, missing in the sense that they have not been made publicly available. It is a chapter concerned with the status of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union as an organised criminal outfit in its own right, a chapter which makes certain recommendations as to the future course of commission of inquiry activities based on the status of that organisation. All the other things which have been the subject of so much intense speculation in recent days have not been the subject of presentation to us now. A lot more could be said about the pros and cons of tabling sensitive material and material which, as the Commissioner says, might well be the subject of further criminal prosecutions and a degree of prejudice to those involved if the publicity runs at this early stage.

I would not wish it to be thought, however, that there is already a well established principle in Australia that no royal commission or similar reports are ever tabled if they name individuals who may subsequently be the subject of criminal prosecution. That has happened on innumerable occasions in the past and will no doubt happen on innumerable occasions in the future. While it is possible to argue in particular cases that the release of names in the form of a report before criminal prosecutions have taken place can interfere with the course of justice, equally it is possible to argue that where a government is potentially embarrassed by some of the names in question rather too much power is placed in the hands of the government by it having the capacity to stop the publication of reports simply on the ground of the likely prosecution of individuals named within them. One suspects, of course, that there is some such motivation lying behind the Government's obvious unwillingness to table other material arising out of volumes 2 and 3 of this report.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you suggesting that Mr Costigan is motivated by that?

—Mr Costigan has a number of masters to serve, and the Fraser Government is one of them. The very existence of his outfit has been put at risk by the attitudes of the Fraser Government towards his Commission and the profound embarrassment caused by it. I am not surprised that Mr Costigan errs, if indeed he does err, on the side of caution in those parts of his reports where he does things which may be construed as having political significance. I say no more than that.

SPEECH.PARA: I will speak very briefly on the content of this report because it is hoped that there will be some further opportunity to debate it at some later stage before too much time expires. It seems to come to three conclusions: First, that there is an organised criminal group operating in Australia through the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union; secondly, that the law enforcement agencies in this country have been manifestly inefficient in not only identifying the existence of a national organised criminal outfit but also controlling it; thirdly, that we do need some sort of proper organisation to suppress this particular form of organised crime. The report says, that there are three functions involved in the suppression of such crime: The first is the identification of what is happening; the second is the reporting about what is going on and the third is the taking of action in respect of it. I mention all this because the Government has sought in the accompanying statement that Senator Chaney has put down to link what Mr Costigan is saying to the Government 's own proposal for a national crimes commission as being, and I quote the ministerial statement:
. . . the appropriate body to pursue the fight against organised crime.

I simply say no more than this. On my reading of the Costigan report, as brief as it has had to be, I see no justification in anything that Mr Costigan has said for the kind of national crimes commission that this Government seems so bent on implementing. Mr Costigan is undoubtedly saying that there needs to be a continuation of some royal commission-type activity armed with greater investigative powers than his commission has at the moment; secondly, that that body needs to have some reporting responsibilities, both in general terms to government and more specifically to other law enforcement agencies; and, thirdly , that there ought to be some prosecuting arm of such an organisation but not necessarily a prosecuting arm which is formally part of the organisation or, indeed, in any way that closely associated with it. The notion of an all-singing all-dancing national crimes commission which investigates everthing in sight, reports in elaborate and gory detail to the world at large on the progress of those investigations and, simultaneously, has a prosecuting function, is not something that is recommended by Mr Costigan and nothing in my reading of this report, brief as it has been, should I think encourage anyone to draw that particular conclusion.

A case there may be for continued ad hoc royal commissions, of which Mr Costigan's has demonstrated itself to be a model; a case there may be for establishing a special prosecutor of the kind that the Attorney-General is proposing to introduce legislation about this week; a case there may be for having even more effective investigative powers attached to some such royal commssion; but a case for a national crimes commission in the way that it has been articulated so far, at least, by the Government-and there has not been any very coherent articulation of it-is simply not made out and indeed some explicit attacks on the United States Crimes Commission model are evident on page 52 of the report that has just been put down in front of us.

There are many things to be unhappy about as to the timing of the tabling of this document and its adequacy. I think the most that we should be unhappy about is the way that the Government is so obviously intending, and the way it has signalled its intention, to use this particular chapter as the long-awaited support structure for its ideas about a national crimes commission. I do not believe that his document will give the Government any such support and I have no doubt that the much closer scrutiny that we will now be able to give the document overnight will reinforce that conclusion. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of the Capital Territory: Revenue

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Capital Territory, upon notice, on 17 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister's Department aware of any information, disclosed in submissions to it, advice available to it or public documents such as Auditor- General's reports, which suggests that the Department and instrumentalities under the Minister's responsibility are forgoing revenue because of insufficient staff.
(2) How much revenue is alleged to have been forgone.
(3) Approximately how much revenue does the Department estimate may have been forgone.
(4) When did the information or items of information become available to the Minister's Department.
(5) What has been done to improve the situation.
(6) What are the details of any staff rearrangements that have been made as a result of action in this regard.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Capital Territory has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) to (6) Variations in staff numbers can be expected to affect the amount of revenue that can be collected but it is not possible to estimate even approximately how much revenue may have been forgone.
I note that my colleague Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle in respect to Question 1220 on the same subject indicated:

No Government has ever adopted a policy of expanding the number of staff in the Taxation Office (or any other revenue collecting agency) to the point where every dollar of revenue capable of being collected each year is collected. At the same time it does not make good sense to cut staff to the point where substantial revenue is forgone.
A similar position applies in respect of my Department which collects large sums of revenue for municipal and territorial type services provided in the Australian Captial Territory.
The effects of staff numbers on revenue collections are taken into account in seeking and allocating additions to the Department's staff ceiling.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Commonwealth Car Fleet: Australian Capital Territory

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 25 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the present number of passenger cars in the Commonwealth car fleet in the Australian Capital Territory.
(2) Is this number sufficient to cope with the parliamentary transport requirements; if not, what alternative mode of transport is used for (a) Ministers; and (b) 'back bench' members of Parliament.
(3) Are hire cars and taxis used as alternative parliamentary transport; if so, what action is taken to enforce the Public Service Act in respect of public servants engaged in driving these vehicles.
(4) What is the number of 'no contact' reports from private contractors.
(5) How reliable are private contractors in comparison to the Commonwealth car service.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There are 104 passenger cars in the Commonwealth car-with-driver fleet in the Australian Capital Territory. Because of permanent weekly hire-with-driver commitments, vehicles off the road for servicing and repairs and absences of drivers, the average daily availability is about 78.

(2) Because of the need to provide transport for VIP visitors and the daily length of time during which parliament sits, this number is not sufficient to cope with Parliamentary transport requirements.
The alternative modes of transport are- (a) Hire cars, self-drive Commonwealth cars, self-drive contractors' vehicles
(b) Hire cars, taxi cabs as a last resort when the Commonwealth car and hire car resources are exhausted.

(3) Hire cars and taxi cabs are used as alternative parliamentary transport. The responsibility for enforcing provisions regarding any external employment of public servants rests with the Departments which employ them. Effective action in this area is generally dependent upon relevant details being provided to the employing department.

(4) The number of 'no contact' reports from private contractors for the period 1 July 1981 to 19 April 1982 in the Australian Capital Territory was 925 which is less than 1% of the total number of jobs allocated to them. Action is in hand which aims at improving performance in this area.

(5) Commonwealth cars and hire car contractors are in the main reliable and taxi contractors are reliable in non peak periods. In peak periods, particularly during parliamentary sitings when the demand from both the public and private sectors exceeds the number of vehicles available, the availability of taxi cabs in the Australian Capital Territory is affected and delays and missed pick-ups are occasionally experienced.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 9 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: How many residents of Christmas Island have applied for Australian citizenship.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Persons born on Christmas Island on or after 1 October 1958 are Australian citizens. The Christmas Island Amendment Act 1980 which came into effect on 17 December 1980 provides that persons who were ordinarily resident on Christmas Island immediately before the transfer of the Island to Australia on 1 October 1958, who are now ordinarily resident on the Island, in Australia or an external Territory may make a declaration that they wish to acquire Australian citizenship. Forty-six persons have taken advantage of this amendment to acquire Australian citizenship.

Additionally, when the Migration Act was extended to Christmas Island on 23 January 1981, a number of persons temporarily living on the Island were subsequently granted resident status and became eligible for the grant of Australian citizenship. Three hundred and nine such persons have applied.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 10 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the functions of the Institute of Multicultural Affairs.
(2) What has been the total expenditure by the Institute in each financial year since its inception.
(3) What is the staff establishment of the Institute, and how many staff actually work in the Institute.
(4) What outside consultants or advisers have been engaged by the Institute and for what purposes, and what amounts of money have been paid to such consultants, or are to be paid.
(5) What (a) projects or lines of work is the Institute currently engaged on; ( b) when is each of these expected to be concluded and (c) will the results of each be published.
(6) What projects have been concluded, and if any, which have been published.

(7) What functions carried out by or within the ambit of the Institute are distinct from those of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, and what is it about those functions which preclude them being carried out by the Department, or indicate that they will be carried out by the Institute and not the Department.

(8) Is the Institute engaged in policy advising work of any kind to Ministers, and if so, to which Ministers; if it is not currently so engaged, on what occasions has it been in the past and who did it advise.
(9) Has the Institute ever given advice or made available information not otherwise publicised to any organisation other than the Government.
(10) What are the achievements of the Institute in meeting the real needs of Australia's ethnic and multicultural communities.
(11) By whom will the answer to this question be prepared.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Section 6 of the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs Act 1979 states:

1. The primary functions of the Institute are: (a) to have a major role in providing advice to the Commonwealth Government on all matters relating to the achievement of the objects referred to in Section 5; and
(b) to promote those objects by- (i) commissioning and conducting research and studies;
(iii) making information available to members of the Australian community and to particular bodies, organisations or groups within that community;
(iv) conducting promotional and community educational activities; and
(v) establishing a repository of literature and other material relating to the diverse cultures of members of the Australian community.
2. The Institute also has the function of engaging in any other activities that the Council considers conducive to the achievement of the objects referred to in Section 5.

The objects of the establishment of the Institute are- (a) to develop among the members of the Australian community- (i) an awareness of the diverse cultures within that community that have arisen as a result of the migration of people to Australia; and
(ii) an appreciation of the contributions of those cultures to the enrichment of that community.
(b) to promote tolerance, understanding, harmonious relations and mutual esteem among the different cultural groups and ethnic communities in Australia;

(c) to promote a cohesive Australian society by assisting members of the Australian community to share with one another their diverse cultures within the legal and political structures of that society; and

(d) to assist in promoting an environment that affords the members of the different cultural groups and ethnic communities in Australia the opportunity to participate fully in Australian society and achieve their own potential.
(2) The expenditure by the Institute in each financial year has been: 1979-80-$ 257,816
(3) The staff ceiling for 30 June 1983 is 35 full-time and 8 part-time staff. At 31 July 1982, 30 full-time and 4 part-time staff were employed.
(4) Since the inception of the Institute in February 1980, 81 consultants or advisers have been engaged.

Consultants or advisors have been drawn from a variety of fields and have included research organisations; academics; management consultants; social workers; economists; former public servants from relevant areas; and people involved in ethnic organisations.

These outside consultants or advisors have been engaged to provide reports on, or to assist in, specific Institute work projects. These have included the ' Review of Multicultural and Migrant Education'; the 'Review of the On-Arrival Education Program'; the development of an in-depth television series provisionally entitled the 'Migrant Experience'; the demographic study 'A Profile of the Italian Community of Australia'; a similar study of the Greek Australian community; and the 'Evaluation of Post-Arrival Programs and Services' .
$388,000 has been paid by way of fees to consultants and advisors.
At 2 August 1982 $8,220 was to be paid to consultants and advisors.

(5) The major projects or lines of work currently being carried out by the Institute are: The production of a television series in conjunction with Film Australia provisionally entitled the 'Migrant Experience'. Completion is anticipated in 1983. The series will be broadcast.
A book and associated materials complementary to the television series are being produced, and are expected to be completed in 1983. They will be published .
A longitudinal study of the impact of multicultural television. Data from this study is included in the 'Evaluation of Post-Arrival Programs and Services'.
A demographic study of the Greek community in Australia. Completion is anticipated during 1982. The report will be published.
An annotated checklist entitled the 'Disabled Migrant; covering bibliographical material. The project will be concluded in the course of 1982. A report will be published.
Preliminary work for a study on the mobility of migrants. The publication of a report is proposed.
Preliminary work for a study of the needs of the ethnic aged, and the provisions made for their care. The publication of a report is proposed.
(6) The following major projects have been concluded: a review of multicultural and migrant education. The report has been published.
a review of the On-Arrival Education Program. The report has been published.
a profile of the Italian community in Australia. The report has been published.
an evaluation of post-arrival programs and services. The report has been published.

(7) The functions of the Institute as detailed in the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs Act 1979 are distinct from those of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in that they are based on the statutory responsibilities of the Institute to promote and assist in the development of a multicultural society.

(8) The Institute's recent evaluation of the Review of Post-Arrival programs and Services for Migrants contains advice to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and to the Commonwealth Government, as did its Review of Multicultural and Migrant Education and the Review of the On-Arrival Education Program. The Institute has been represented on a number of Committees formed to offer advice to the Commonwealth Government such as a review of ethnic radio, the teaching of English on multicultural television and the recognition of overseas qualifications.

(9) The Institute has made available advice and information to organisations other than the Government which has not been publicised. Its Act requires it among other things to promote and develop multiculturalism, tolerance, understanding and cohesion and the opportunity to participate fully in Australian society. It is required to give advice and to make information available to the Australian community and to bodies, organisations or groups within that community. A number of statutory authorities, State organisations, ethnic organisations and single individuals have all sought information and advice, which has not been publicised.
(10) The major projects completed by the Institute are outlined in the answer to question 6.

(11) The answer presented to this question represents the Minister's views and information provided by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs.
